text: 750ml bottle at the 3 Fonteinen restaurant. Golden Blend Oude Geuze bottling date 12/12/2014. Aroma of dusty, musky, horse blanket, light to moderate vinegar, oak. Taste is young, with quite strong farm flavour, goat, oak, musky, cellar. Aftertaste is moderate to very sour, with a touch of toasted barley. Really good, but it will most likely be even better after some more years of aging.

kolor złocisty piana obfita dość szybko opada.
Zapach to czyste uderzenie spoconych koni husarii. xD A tak serio to jest mega dziko, troszkę skórek owoców w tle ale derka na pierwszym planie. Z czasem pojawia sie cytryna
smak jest wybitnie skórzany i cierpki jak niektóre owce. Czuć nuty gorzkich pomarańczy i ogólnie owocowe ale ciężko mi nazwać co to może być, może agrest? Kwaśność jak na Geuze to niska do umiarkowanej.
Wysycenie średnie bo sie odgazowało dość. 
Bardzo fajna faktura która pozostawia suchy i ściągający efekt po przełknięciu. Piwo WYBITNE i jedno z najlepszych Geuze jakie wypiłem

A golden Gueuze with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet fruity lactic malt with horse blanket, grapeskin, ground cherries, lactic acid, Epsom salts, beautiful mix of beauty. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity malt with ground cherries, lactic acid, Epsom salts, very nice and smooth, yet complex.

Bottle in garden 2013 bottle, 13th May 17. Pours a rich dark straw colour, big head, that dissipates to a clean head. Aroma is cellar, funk, lots going on. Taste is cellar, slight tart, wood, wet barrel, vineous, aged blanket. Complex and delicious aged geuze.

375ml bottled 2011-02-17, best before 2021-02. Kept in a perfectly control environment, 14 degree Celsius and no light. Pour dark orange almost copper without foam. Aroma is of old wood, green apple and aromatic vinegar. Taste is tart, woody, earthy and apple cider. Medium body and low carbonation. Dry and slick. Long funk finish.
Bottled. 20cl sample. The aroma has funks, oak, lemons, red apples. Bit hazy, orange coloured, with a white head. The taste is light bitter, funky, bit grassy, has apples, funk and leather. Good one.

Fantastic bear with peache color, small head and soft carbonation. In aroma grapefruits, lemons, bretts, barn, wood and leather. Also green apples and a little bit of vinegar. In taste big citric, funky, wood, grape skin, apricot and wine. Fantastic beer!

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Rami Rami is drinking an Oude Geuze Golden Blend by Brouwerij 3 Fonteinen at Chmielarnia Marszałkowskamocno skorzany, sporo winogron, pestkowy, reszta jak pan jp2 przykazal, klasaOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

Perfect.....nothing less! It seems like the age of the 2011 is very right at the moment. Everything is in play and in perfect balance. Beautiful light but very deep amber body...the deepest and most complex nose of any Oude Geuze I remember having tasted....the body so well balanced and so drinkable.....the finest of any drinking experiences....the finest of any artistic experiences.....thanks
Great one, very nice lambic notes in aroma and in taste. Moderate sourness, very balanced. Huge beer.
Bue en bouteille de 37,5cl. Blonde claire. Peu de CO2. Pas mon style de bière donc difficile pour moi à décrire, mis à part une grosse acidité évidemment. Correcte

375ml bottle. Pours a hazy ruby gold, with a smallish off-white head, which lasts well and leaves a little lacing. Leather, oak, sour cherry and citrus peel make for an enticing aroma. Strong sourness up front offers sour cherry and grapefruit, leading into a woody, leathery mid-palate. The finish is fresh and sour, with floral notes. As always with 3 Fonteinen, this is exceptionally delicious.

0,375l bottle at home. Bottled 12/03/2014. BB 12/03/2024. amber cloudy color, small white head. smells musty, citric, green apples, some funk, grassy, nutty, some marzipan, bit salty, quite lovely smell, especially after it got some air. full body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes citric, musty, some funk, light sour fruits, quite salty, green apples, some wood, mineralic. finishes rather dry, rather sour and salty with notes of green apples, light sour fruits and notes of citrus. wasnt so amazed by the smell at first but after some breathing the smell improved quite a bit, lovely lovely taste. lovely refreshing especially for the ABV.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

Bottle shared by Travlr at the nuplastik returns tasting at iphonefans. Cloudy orange-gold with small offwhite head. Tart and musty citrus and hay, slight barnyard funk, wood, grains, yeast. Complex and zesty. Very nice.
Bottle. Hazy, orangish, no head. Barnyard, leather, citric, green apples and funky. Medium bodied, high carbonation, very dry and tart finish. Great beer.

375ml bottle pours out a hazy gold topped with a white head. Nose is nice funk wood barnyard citrus lemongrass and the classic 3fonteinen yeast. Taste is more of the nice funky barnyard a nice citrus touch.

You can compare this a bit to the vintage oude geuze but I think this one is even more flavoured and maybe more citrus flavor.

Grea great geuze, one of the best I ever had in my life.

375ml bottle dated 12/03/2014. Semi-clear dark golden with no head. Aroma is dry and funky with grains, hay, stable- and barnyard notes, overripe automn fruits and light acidity. Dry taste with fairly low acidity, some funk, hay, slight burnt notes, earthiness, passing citric and fruity apple cider vinegar-like notes, barnyard and wood. Light, prickly mouthfeel, no carbonation and discrete but complex aftertaste.

375 mL bottle. Bottled 2/17/2011. Reviewed from notes.

Darker than 3F Oude Geuze. Big head, no retention. Surprising. Faint, discrete bubbles.

Smells citrusy. Lemon and orange. Its more prominent than the funk. Deep earthy, but not overwhelming cheese aroma behind it.

Tastes extremely citrusy, which I didnt expect. Orange and lemon behind it. Less funk than the smell, but still an earthy oaky funk. Light body and very dry in the finish.

Light and very carbonated. Effervescent and dry. Sour, but not overly so.

Excellent, maybe not better than regular Oude Geuze. I might even say its monotonic in its citric notes.

2011 375mL bottles consumed fairly young (Summer 2013) and again on 8/3/16.Great pour to it, with large amounts of white head showing moderate to moderately-strong retention for the style. Clear, brass-golden body shows fine carbonation.The nose is full of brett, as youd expect from 3F, with huge amounts of soft lime, hickory nut skin and very light band aid. Its atop a seemingly dry malt/wheat base showing bits of biscuit and honey. Some very light oak, but in the background, with mineral, wet hay and light horseblanket. Its very "lively" with lots of tangy fruit and such, though it doesnt (to me) remind anything of Blauw. Still, its wonderfully clear, funky and bright with, of course, no flaw or alcohol.In the mouth, it proves quite delicate, with strong attenuation, as expected, fine carbonation and a soft, wheat-like texture. Hay, horse, tons of brett acids and just a hint of honey on the end mixing with light oak, pleasantly. It does gain quite a bit of green apple, not really seen from the nose, which is odd. Im not the biggest fan of green apple character in lambics. It sort of reminds of Boon, whose lambics I dont care for. Other than that, its got all the makings of a light, bubbly, easygoing and very drinkable gueuze.  I also preferred it more when it was younger, as the flavors all seemed brighter, sharper and more challenging.
2014 bottle pours a dark gold color. Slight white head. Medium mouthfeel. High carbonation. Peach nose.

375 ml bottle v2011 shared with Nightfall at his place. Thank you Alex!! Cloudy golden color with white to off white head. Yeasty and light malty aroma, funky dusty, light barnyard, citrusy fruity, tart lemon and orange, wood. Sweet, light acidic and light bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.
Wonderful complex and delicious. Aroma is of funky chalk cellar. Carbonation is low but not too low. Flavor starts tart with some minerals, grapefruit, funky grasses. Finish is nicely bitter dry.

Bouteille(17/2/2011): Deep golden, hazy, big and stable loose white head; citric acid, apples, vinegar and traces of old yeast in the nose, bretty aromas in the background; solid sour and slightly bitter flavour, medium bodied and relatively soft; lingering sour and also bitter finish with a solid dash of citric acid and cidery flavours. A superb Gueuze with a nice and well rounded bitterness...
From a bottle at the Sovereign in Georgetown. Pours a cloudy copper with an off white head. Wonderful barnyard funk aroma. Flavors of sour white grapes and dank hay. Smooth tart finish.

Transparent burnt golden color, frothy off-white head. Lemon, funk, must, white grape, and tart pear. Taste is less sour than the aroma - wood, tannin, and funk. Strangely soft carb, light body, and a clean finish.
Dark golden pour, white head; high carb. Nose is caramel, funk, lemon, some leather. Taste is bright citrus, lemony, caramel, a touch of leather, some oxidation.

0.75 l bottle from Uba ja Humal, Tallinn. Bottle dated 12/12/2014. Aroma is sourish but mainly fruity. Appearance is light amberish, like faro. Sparkling, but settles fast. Taste is dry, as expected, but not sour or extremely dry. Taste of wood is overwhelming. More smooth than most of the other gueuzes.
金色较浑浊酒 gueze。

Bottle to tulip. Wild funk aroma with slight floral aspects. Hazy golden yellow with moderately large white head that retains well. Taste is magnificent - blend of barnyard which predominates, along with fruity and slight malt character. Beautiful.
Une très belle gueuze tout en puissance et complexité, avec une bouche longue et acidulée avec une très grande persitance.
Bottle from churchkey. Pours clear straw lots of head and lacing. Nose is tart vinegar and plum. Flavours lemon, vinegar, plums, some grapefruit. Taste big tart light sweet. Full sticky body.

Vinegar tartness, with a slight rubber and slight oak to the smell. Deep full glowing orange, with very active lasting head. Smooth body slides down, with beautiful oak tartness. So smooth the funk is balance perfect to the balance. Almost grapefruit juice mouth feel.

37,5 cl bottle. Golden, darker than most gueuzes. Lots of barnyard flavours, citrusy. Some sweetness and a very sour finish. Very good one. Not sure it is worth the price though, even at belgium price. But well worth trying once.

Drunk from 375 cl bottle bought direct from 3 Fonteinen blending house. Superb blend of lambic and deceptively strong.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled 12/3/2014. Pours a golden copper with a slight haze. Beige head with good carbonation that sticks around longer than most lambics. The nose is sour, sour fruit, acidic, and some oak. Taste is again sour fruit and acidic, tart and dry, very refreshing. Carbonation and MF are both perfect for this style. Very pleasant to drink but pretty expensive.

Bottle. Aroma is potent sour grape, white wine, apricot, and cranberry, with a little wheat in the mix together with faint oak and a little burnt match and cork. Hazy orange appearance under a lasting, lacy, rocky white cover. Sour grape, cork, cranberry, apricot, and white wine flavour with a moderate to medium oaky bitterness and moderate horseblanket. Dry and mouth puckering. Medium high carbonation, light body.

Trübes orange goldenes Bier mit mittelgroßen leicht beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht säuerlich, Kräuter, Strauch, leicht fruchtig trocken. Geschmack säuerlich fruchtig, trocken, Kräuter, Strauch, mild fruchtig.

(3 Fonteinen Oude Geuze Golden Blend) Corked and caged bottle 375 ml at home, served into a big tulip, ABV 7.5%
Bright copper orange colour on the body, tall and frothy white head on top, with good retention though. Good activity in the glass.
Nice aroma with grapes, wood, cork, dust.
Taste is mildly sour with grapes, wood, cork, apples.
Medium thin body, good carbonation , nicely tart on the palate.
Great.

Het Aroma geeft een minder hoge verwachting dan hetgeen je zal krijgen. Qua smaak is dit echt één van de grootste innovaties op biervlak van de afgelopen vijf jaar. Hopelijk wordt de productie hiervan snel omhoog geschroefd.

03/2014 Vintage: Consumed 02/2016.

AROMA: Tropical more straight off the bar. Earthy, petrichor. Dank cellar, dry, woody. Amazing. 

APPEARANCE: A Deep amber with an orange hue. Very lively, a good clean white head which lasts.

TASTE: The taste is pretty damn complex. Tropical fruit namely pineapple along with green apples. Subdued fink although I had a noble of blue cheese alongside and this thing just came alive with pure funk dank funkyness.

PALATE: Rich, decadent, syrupy, quenching, mega carbonated. Oily mouthfeel, very sour.

OVERALL: Pricey but worth the money. It really is a step up on am already outstanding drink. Love it.

7,5% ABV, 37,5 cl. imbottigliata il 12 Marzo 2014, aperta il 19 Febbraio 2016.
Arancio con riflessi dorati, schiuma bianca tendente al giallo di ottima persistenza.
Aroma di pompelmo, pesca e mango, legno umido, polvere, pepe, sudore equino, lievemente oleosa, pungente al punto giusto, frumento ed erbaceo tagliato di fresco.
Al palato pompelmo e pesca, uva bianca, legno umido, mandorla tostata, polvere, frumento, lievemente astringente, note di miele, coda molto complessa caratterizzata da legno, polvere, erbaceo, pompelmo, uva bianca.
Corpo medio-leggero, non molto carbonata, texture oleosa, pericolosamente beverina.

375 mL bottle shared by Gus with ebone1988 and I. The pour is a dark bubbly gold with a thicker white head that remains as a film and thick collar. The aroma is very, very acidic. There is a heavy battery acid thing happening, and it's not good. The it's got a nice sour on the back end, but it's just way too acidic. The flavor is all battery acid. It's heavily acidic. Not good at all. There is a nice sour that builds, but it's impossible to drown out the acidity. The mouth feel is light and crisp with a bubbly carbonation and a lingeringly acidic aftertaste. It's heavy acid, that's for sure. It has chance but this thing needs to mellow out a few years. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with koleminer20 and Gus. Aroma is funk, sour, some wheat, barnyard, good. Appearance is golden, white head, slight haze. Taste is sour as hell, barnyard, funky, wet hay, amazing. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, crisp carbonation, funky wet hay aftertaste. Overall, this is very very good.

Nose is complex funk with layered mushroom, damp wood, basement, stonefruit, orange, lemon and hayfield. Taste holds the complexity of the nose, medium acidity, dry, bretty orange and grass, dusty cheese and lemon. Finishes tart, mix of funky hay, dusty attic, fuzzy stonefruit, cheesy must. World class blend.

0.375l bottle thanks to Lore. Hazy dark orange body, off white head. Aroma of lemon zest, salt, cheese and coriander. Taste of salt, lemon juice, coriander and candi sugar. Very tart and complex. Awesome.

Bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is very fruity and funky. Vinegary, sour, gooseberries, grapes, barnyard. Taste is sour, green apples, light acid, vinegar, oaky, some barnyardy notes.

Hazy golden brown color. Intense nose of gooseberry, oak, fruit in the nose. Very light body, decent acidity, light body. Lots of oak cobweb and fruitness. Nice cobweb, horse leather finish. The oak just lingers. Fantastic.

Amber coloured beer with a small and stable white head. Fresh and sour aroma. Full bodied beer with a complex and very well balanced sour flavour. (Corked bottle 37,5cl)

opalescent golden colour, moderate sized off-white head; aroma of intensive fruitiness (apple, maybe some peach and grape, too), tart, some balsamic acid, wood, earthy and minimal leather notes; taste is dominated by acidic sourness with woody notes, citruses, sour apple and some tart, maybe bread; great gueuze

375ml bottle from Systembolaget, ABV 7.5%. Hazy deep golden with a medium size fizzy white head, some lacing. Great aroma, green apples, funk, stables, earth, straw and hay. Smooth, juicy, tart, fizzy mouthfeel. Very big taste, green apples, apple cider, funk, hay, oak, lemon. Dry, crisp finish that really stuck in my teeth.

375 ml cork bottle bought at The Bottle Shop in Sai Kung.
Preparation: Fridged bottle, popped at 10°C -12°C (within recommended temperature of 14°C) onto a Westmalle chalice.

Looks: Translucent amber liquor colour with a ring of dirt-like yeast sediments; No head, no foams, no lacing nor carbonation detected.

Aroma: Very fragrant and tart aroma of malt, with strong red wine, Port wine, Balsamic vinegar, strong yoghurt, grape skins, strong funk, strong tannic, wood barrel and strong lemon.

Taste: Strong sour taste of malt, with strong funk, strong grape skins, moderate Balsamic vinegar, strong yoghurt, red wine, strong wood barrels, strong tannin, strong lemon, strong bitter hops and light grass.

Body: Close to light body. Thin and quite slick palate.

Mouth Feel: Wow, nothing prepares me for this! Funky to start, then with very strong but pleasant yoghurt tartness and strong grape skins and tannin, complimented by moderate red wine and Balsamic vinegar. Strong barrel make it like an aged wine. Not in-your-face but mature and delicious!

Hoppiness / Tannic: Strong lemon and grape skins in nose. Strong lemon, very astringent grape skin, strong tannic and light grass in taste. Bitterness is moderate to strong for a lasting, very astringent winey finish.

After Taste: Fairly dry. Funky, very winey and bitter to mouth.

Comments: This is a definite step up to the original Oude Geuze. Its a lot bolder in tartness, yet very expressive in the barrel and winey taste. The total lack of head and carbo doesnt matter, as the sophisticated taste and feel make up for it. A winner for Christmas!

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2016 Tasting bij Maakun. Ruikt heerlijk hooiig, zuur is stevig maar mild vanwege mooie balans met smaak en champagneachtig koolzuur. Enorm kruidig en fruitig! Drinkplezier! Backlog from 2015/09/08.
Shared bottle at deansos. strong aroma, woody, almond, very nice.

Limited edition of 3 Fonteinen Oude Geuze with a much higher dose of old lambic than is custom in geuze blending. Lot of pressure on the 37.5 cl bottle, but no gushing. Initially creamy, off-white, fairly loose but stable, medium sized head, colour is a lightly hazy warm orange blonde with lively fizz, inevitably cloudy with the yeast deposit added. Strong aroma indeed reveals the noblesse and unmistakable maturity of old lambic, pungent yet restrained at the same time, with all kinds of things going on: redcurrant, Cape gooseberry, dry sherry, lime juice, mouldy orange, unripe apricot, damp hay, old cheese, wet wood, very old books, wet leather, even manure but in this type of beer, that very, lets say earthy feature doesnt bother me. Crisp onset with a lot of spritzy, champagne-like carbonation tickling the tongue and enlightening the body; lots of fruity esters as expected, with hints of gooseberry, fresh lemon, pink grapefruit and blueberry, drying acidity as expected but in a somewhat mellow, gentle kind of way, not as puckering and lemony as in more classically made oude geuzes, though lemon acidity is certainly there, stretches deep into the finish and is in beautiful balance with the calmer lactic acidity; a notably (very) dry white wine-like character appears in the middle and stays till the end, supported by clean barley and wheat flavours in the background. Finish is truly beautiful: the ongoing drying lemon peel acidity still balanced with the soft lactic tartness, a softly bittering earthiness of old hops for structure, a drying woodiness and a retronasal feast of sweetish and sourish fruity esters and the infamous horseblanket. The aftertaste seems deeper, thicker, more sherryish (even very vaguely sweetish) and also more bitter than that of the regular version. Difficult to judge: this is a splendid example of the style for sure, but I cannot quite decide whether I like it more than the regular one. Just absolutely great, lets say, and without a doubt different from his regulary made oude geuze not just in composition, but in terms of flavour as well.
This is awesome. Helloooo oak aroma and flavor. Pour is gold with some white head. Flavor is super tart and oaky and smooth. Id like to drink this daily.

Clear golden amber pour with a very tall head with decent retention. Funky barnyard smell, citric acid, sulfur, typical geuze stuff. The taste is sour as hell, apple vinegar style, salty as well, with a strong bitterness underneath. Surprisingly refreshing and apparently it goes well after a spicy meal.

Bottle @ Dolle, thanks a lot! Pours hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma of funk, tart, quite a lot of wood, fruity. Taste has a sweet finish, fruity, tart, wood, funk. Well balanced and very enjoyable!
Bottle. Thx Dolle. Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma of funk, barn, grapes, light green apples, woody, tart. Very enjoyable!
Bottle. Hazy golden body with a huge fluffy offwhite head. Dusty, dry, lime, yeast, lemon, tart, oak. Wow this is very good. Easy drinkable. Smooth.

2011 vintage from the wicker basket, Akkurat, Stockholm, 31/10/15. Hazed gold with excitable carbonation and a strong white fluff of collar fading fast. Dank cheesy hay, piss, mellow lime and tart apple nose. Signature mellow lime and cream with a sherbet and pineapple cube tartness mellowed by funk and sweet time. Really rounded, dank and bright with sherbet and sour apple. Highly approachable, sessionable little lambic. Were it not 275Kr a bottle.

Bottled: 2011/02/17

Upon loosening the cage, the cork came out with a loud pop. Lots of pressure but not a gusher at all. Pours a very hazy, dark golden orange color with tangerine edges and a two finger yellowish-beige head that slowly settles into a thick, lasting ring. Streaks of soapy lacing left behind. 

Musty, funky aroma with a strong barnyard presence along with lactic funk, citric acidity and light fruit. Earthy with lots of oak, cobweb, grass, wet hay and horsebkanket followed by lactic cheese, lemon juice and green apple. Smells very inviting but it seems like the four year old portion of the blend tones things down a bit. 

On the fuller end of medium bodied with tight carbonation and a tart, puckering flavor that lingers over the lactic funk, citrus, light fruit and pale malt into a crisp, dry finish. Aggressively sour at first but not harsh or overly acidic with lots of earthy oak, lactic funk and sweet citrus balancing things out. As it warms, the lactic cheesy presence stands out a bit more and the citrus acidity becomes a bit more tart. Earthy with toasted oak, grass and hay notes countered by lemon peel and green apple flavors. Funky and sour but well balanced and very quaffable and refreshing once the palate adjusts. I could drink gallons of this stuff if it wasnt so damn expensive.

(Bottle, bottled 2011) Dark golden colour with frothy, off-white head, leaving traces of lacing. Fruity, sourish nose with apricots, unripe peaches, grapefruit, orange, green apples, stable, cellar and hay. Fruity, tart taste with notes of hay, apples, grapefruit, orange, cellar, oak wood and a fresh sourness in a dry finish with a light grassy bitterness. Medium body, dry. Very tasty and well made with a fresh sourness. In excellent balance. Possibly a bit more crisp than the "ordinary" oude gueuze. Lovely beer!

Rating #1265 - Bottle from CBI (2011) - 02.10.2014 -Pours hazy golden with a bubbly white head. Aroma of orange peel, lemon juice, Brett, barnyard. Quite tart and juicy with a pronounced sourness - lingering acidity into the finish. Extraordinary.

2015 bottle
The aroma is very special, some hay, some marshmallows, a bit of barn.. But very, very nice. The appearance is perfect, rather dark, brown, Orange a thick head that stays well and is white..
Tastes amazing, a champagne feel, but with wonderful deep flavor af sweet apples and caramel.. A complexity in the taste yet easy to drink.. UPDATED: FEB 13, 2016 Oude geuze Golden Blend 14 vintage

Pours a saturated, bright, golden-amber color, with a small, fizzy head, receding to a thin, bubbly texture at the rim of the glass. 

On the nose, the beer produces an incredibly intense funkiness. It features green apple peel, crisp citrus wrapped up in blue cheese, leather, prickling mushroom, jogurt, and most surprisingly a pleasant floral note. All those flavors blend together marvellously, creating a very harmonious, aroma bursting impression. 

Has a soft, medium carbonation with a pleasant mouthfeel to it, refreshing due to citrus and mineralic tones, silk on the tongue due to a buttery, leather defined maltiness.

Tastes of a slowly unfolding citrus crispness, featuring a luscious sourness, next to a more and more pungent developing dryness. Dusty old earth produces a great balance, with a moldy toffee sweetness to be found in it. Its carbonation adds a vivid component to the drinking experience, masking the bigger body of this perfectly well. Finishes with an intense, mineral supported, citrus dryness among fermented green apple, sun bathed hay and a wheaty sweetness.

A treat throughout, pushing the already best Geuze even further. Everything I love about their regular Gueuze is detectable in this, while they amped it up a bit. Best example for this being the nose, promising an uncompromising funkiness, countered by its characteristic crispness on the palate, achieving an intriguing synergy, which lasts till the end. Unbelievable depth of flavors, while its balance is just spot on.

Funk tuned down a bit, still smooth musty, leathery notes. Sour intensity from medium to high, a little less when the beer warms up. Aftertaste consists mostly from zesty sour with some brilliant strawberry and oak notes at the far end. 


Mouthfeel: Fresh, crisp, fizzy carbonation, medium body. Very dry and coats your mouth with time. Classic geuze.


Overall: The smell is mind-blowing. Complex, balanced, smooth, the most impressive funk witnessed. And the taste that follows does its job (maybe a bit high on sour for my taste, but hell, cant complain about that). Superb and well worth your time and money.

Over the years Ive pretty much fallen out of love with sour beers, but I still revisit now and then for fun...theyre neat in their own way, but I just dont crave the bacteria-laden stuff anymore. That said, Drie Fonteinen has long been a favorite in this genre, so visiting Akkurat meant perusing the bottle list. And when I spotted this, I decided it was about time to say hello to Armands handiwork again, partly because its a 2-3 year old bottle and thus in the typical sweet spot for geuze. This takes me back to my visit to Heeren van Liedekercke many years ago to sample the special 3F J&J blends...this has the same sort of mastery of blending that those had; its very sour but not TOO sour (near perfect balance for my tastes), its remarkably complex aromatically and almost shockingly fruity (as if peaches were added, seriously) with zero undesirable odors, and overall its pretty much impossible not to love.

Rich, complex nose - lemon juice, sour candy, horse-blanket, soft tart wheat, just a tiny hint of bitter orange lurking underneath. Dry, lively, some grainy malt but its really defined by the yeast - soft lemon, slightly sweaty, green apple skins, a hint of creamy oak, just a tiny tiny hint of balsamico and some tannin on the finish. Very complex, very satisfying, but it just doesnt quite beat a Cantillon for me.

(bottled 2011, 37.5cl) Hazy, golden colour with a big but diminishing slightly off-white frothy head. Moderately acidic fruity aroma with woody notes and a mild barnyard character. Moderately acidic and tart flavour, light to medium bodied with a sparkling carbonation. Bone-dry and mildly wheaty lambic character with sour-fruity notes of citrus and hints of barnyard and old oak barrels; well-embedded vinegary and tannic notes are lingering into the aftertaste. Superb. 06.VI.13

37.5cl bottle (2011). Deep golden with thin white head. Aroma is full of lemon rind, pithy lime, leather, barnyardy yeast funk, orange peel, leather, light sea salt: Christ, this is a fine smelling blend. Taste gives deep and tart citrus fruits, loads of lemon and lime, barnyard dusty-ness, sour sour lemons, light sweatiness, damp leather. So smooth. Wonderfully balanced sourness. Heavenly nectar for sourheads.

RATING #4000!!!! Clear orange tinted light copper glow with even a hint of a pink glow too with no head at all to speak of. Aroma of pure and simple mouth watering sourness with a great yeast smell, some light apples and pears, a hint of cherries and that amazing bubble gum sourness. Light-bodied; Sour flavour at first with a big yeast note then an immediate turn to oak and dry herbal flavours with some light fruits. Aftertaste strong and pungent with the herbal and yeast notes coming together and showing a hint of sourness, but not much. Good and complex, but perhaps not showing as much sourness and depth as other geuze. Overall, an amazing beer and a great one to sample if you can find it - not my favourite geuze, but one that I wish I could afford/find/have all the time! I sampled this 4000th rating, a 37,5 cL bottle purchased from Bier Tempel in Bruxelles, Belgium on 30-June-2012 (my last birthday) for 7,95 sampled at home in Washington on 20-May-2013 in celebration of Detroit beating Chicago in Game 3 of the 2013 Stanley Cup Playoffs. The middle beer - beer #5 of 9 from the 4000th rating celebration! Lot Number/Date: 17-February-2011, best by 02-2021.

Pours golden with high frothy white head
Aromas of bretta, apricots, sour fruits, honey
Taste is lovely with a sweet smooth ess and great sour ending. Oranges, apricots, lemons with dashes of honey. Hreat!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml bottle shared with Albatross. Pours an opaque brownish golden with a resilient yellowish white head. Aroma is fruits, wild yeast, old, jungle, oranges. Flavor is a lot of yellow grapefruit, wild strawberry field (including the hay), field raspberries, honey. Finish is extremely tart, acidic, grapefruit bitterness, a floral touch, "sweet tart" candies. Old, dusty, yet so refreshing. Medium to strong body, medium to strong carbonation. A unique experience, an unforgettable beer.
Ljust grumlig, guldig. Väldigt druvig smak. Mycket mycket citrus på slutet. Njutbar öl !

Pours a rich golden color with a big frothy white foam that sticks around as the aromas open up like a dusty old trunk. Big funky wood notes jump from the glass with touches of juicy stonefruit, leather, dust and old dried lemon peel. The palate follows with amazing complexity yet balanced elegance. This beer fuckin rocks ! Love the integration of funk fruit and dust.... YUM !

Bottle, 375ml -  Semi hazy orange beer with a small fizzy head. Aroma is spicy with notes of red berries, citrus, bretty funkiness and some oak. Flavor is tart with a huge grapefruit and citrus punch with hints of bretty leather. Finish is rather sweet for this type of beer. Not as complex as I had expected, but a fantastic beer nonetheless.

A - Hazy golden-orange with a finger of frothy white head. Fades normal.

S - Sweet wheat, vanilla, oak, tart green fruits, funky barnyard yeast, some sourness, lemon zest.

T - Sweet wheat and other grainy malts, tart green fruits, oak, vanilla, barnyard funky yeasts, a bit of sourness, lemon zest.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a funk, dry, and tart finish.

D - Great complex and smooth gueuze.
Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours golden with white head. Lots of carbonation. Huge oak flavors with a puckering sour finish.

Bottle at the DISOB tasting, Den Haag. Poured a clear medium amber with a thin white head. The aroma is yeast, fruit and the sourness is there  too. The flavour is big sour,  grapefruit and strongly acidic.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2015 Bottle shared at the "Deans scared of beer tasting".  Pours clear amber golden with a ring off white head.  Aroma of barnyard funk, tart fruit and horse blanket.  Flavor is heavy sour.  Medium to full bodied with light carbonation

Bottle shared at the "Deans scared of beer tasting"
Thin white head.  Clear golden aroma.  Sour taste.  Not my cup of tea.

Opened up for game 5 of the Hawks-Wild playoff series. Poured into a vintage Oud Beersel tumbler. Pours a translucent brownish yellow/orange in color with about a fingers worth of off-white head. There is excellent head retention for minutes after pouring. Nose is uncharacteristically faint for a 3F gueuze to me, maybe it just hasnt opened up enough yet? Faint lemon rind, stone fruit, must, and horse blanket. The flavor is more alive despite being a little muted still. Sharp lemon rind, a healthy dose of mineral, and some gentle funk on the finish. Mouthfeel is a little watery and light, but the carbonation is lively, the acidity is puckering, and the finish is moderate in length. Ive liked every bottle Ive opened of this so far, but this seems to be a little bit of a letdown for some reason. For the money, Id much rather just have an OGV or an aged 3F Oude geuze. Regardless, Armand is still the man and this is delicious.

Bottle corked. Poured clear copper color with a large frothy off-white head that was lasting with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sour yeast wood aroma. Medium to full body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Medium sour citrus flavor with a medium sour finish of moderated duration. This is a standout for style beer.

Det här var en bra öl men jag måste ändå säga att jag var besviken, jag hade väntat mig ännu mer. Vilket kanske var lite dumt. Smaken är välbalanserad och härligt syrlig. Kanske lite för mycket kolsyra om man ska vara extra petig, och det ska man ju.

Two-year-old bottle, shared with VT. The cork exploded violently upon loosing. Lots of protein; hyper frothy; big bubbles. The smell is also powerfully intense. I had to pull back the first time I put my nose in the glass, before I could appreciate  all the floral and fruity aromas radiating through the brettanomyces: berries, pear, peach, macintosh apple, cherry. The taste is sharply acidic, with flavors of wild fruits and plants (familiar to me, in Canada): wild raspberry and gooseberry, sweet clover, and lilac petal. It leaves a pleasant after-taste of grapefruit while the unending acidity cleans the enamel off your teeth. Im not even half- joking here. This beer is an hyperbole.

pours almost clear golden with a decent white head, some retention. funk, fresh wheat and tropical lemons, wood, some apples, wine and apple wine, granny smith acidity, other fresh greeness - very refreshing. very few acetic notes. tad more fruit acidity than regular oude geuze. bright carbonation, light body - some texture thouh, very dry and astringent finish. very enjoyable.

Bottle. Clear orange liquid with a huge fluffy white head. Small bubbles and a high level of carbonation. Aroma: Funky, horseblanket, barnyard, citrus, slightly musty, apples, sour fruits, complex, funky, really nice! Taste: medium sourness with a balanced amount of funk, tart, sour apples, citrus, barnyard and hay, slightlymusty, earthy. Really nice geuze!
Apple jumps out at uncorking! Head is ginormous. Colour surprisingly amber tinted. Near perfect taste. Lovely

375ml corked bottle and served in my Ratebeer Old School Tulip (and paired with Roth Grand Cru cheese wedge) :  Beautiful golden hue with a mostly lasting fizzy head and okay lace. The aroma has moderate sweaty funk, cheese, oak, acidity, mineral, horsey, flowery and just a touch of herbs. The taste is so well balanced between the pale grains, oak barrels and wild yeasts, not overly sourd nor overly funky but a great combination of the depth of palate. The mouth feel is lively and crisp with only moderate oak tannins. This is well done indeed, too bad it cost so much.
Smell is sour and a little funky.  Very acidic/vinegar type smell.  Oak flavor is very subtle.  For a sour beer this is pretty drinkable.

Golden, slight haze, white head.  Dry, grainy and biscuity malt, nice sourness with light acidity, apricots, apples, hay, citrus tartness, some lemon, dusty earthiness, nice lingering tartness in finish.

0.375l corked bottle from Etré. A little treat on a Thursday afternoon! This is a cloudy almost glowing honey-orange thing with a big massive almost fluffy off-white top. In the aroma I get a bretty woody acidity, lots of old rustic yellow sour apples that has been lying in a old dark cellar for ages. Earth and soil with a whiff of apple wine vinegar. Lovely aroma. Its quite lively on the carbonation this - almost so that it kinda explodes a bit in the mouth. Quite different. Really dry this! Almost no sweetness what so ever. Fruity sour old green apples with brett, earth, wood, apple wine vinegar and some soft hints in the aftertaste that strongly reminds me of gastric acid. This was much dryer than I had imagined, not to mildwrenchingly sour actually and quite refreshing! Good stuff! 11.10.2012

375 ml caged and corked bottle, bottle date of 2011/02/17.  Served in a Unibroue tulip, the beer pours a cloudy golden/orange color with a huge 3 inch off-white frothy head.  The head sticks around a while, and theres also a lot of lacing.  It smells like funk, wood, lemon peel, green apples, and some apricots.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also some green grapes, vinegar and a bit of leather noticeable too.  Also, the flavors are more tart/sour compared to the aroma.  This brew just gets better the longer I drink it!  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick with a good amount of soft, zingy carbonation.  Its very enjoyable and easy to drink.  Good, but pricey at $21.99 a bottle.

Bottle 37,5 cl, bottled on 17/02/2011 and BBE 02/2021. Pours dark golden in color with a frothy head that gets smaller after awhile, but its yet staying on as a small cap for the whole time. Initial aroma was sour lemon, but that turns into some barnyard, funk and old, dry leather later on. Just like being in the countryside on a farm on a warm summerday. Something that is light fruity, perhaps some white grapes that is, is as well there. Dry and quite tart, still theres that fruityness in the background as well. Light wooden oakiness, earthy funkiness and lemon in taste. Seems like this one is extremely well balanced. Tasty and delicious, theres the mild fruityness, light sweetness and the sour notes of gueuze working well together and making this one quite remarkable. A real treat.

Pours hazy golden amber with massive frothy white head - truly golden. Aroma is incredibly fresh and rich with green apples, green grapes, gooseberries, fresh grass, very light earth. Taste is incredibly balanced with an initial light sweetness that turns into a distinct and fresh, rounded sourness before the finish where the sourness mellows down a bit and is complimented by a light sweetness. Mouthfeel afterwards is surprisingly sweet. Body is obviously light and slick with lively but not sharp carbonation. One of the best sour ales Ive had!

375ml bottle, honey gold color, with a bubbly white head, nice musty fruity, dusty, green apple sour nose, with a yeasty funky, bretty, woody, zesty lemon tart, leather, barnyard accent, with an acidic citrus juiciness note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a good juicy lemon acidic, fruity green apple sour, tart, musty green grape, woody white wine tannin character, with a funky, bretty, earty moldy yeasty flavour, leading towards a funky bretty yeastiness, sour green apple, lemon acidic, green grape must, woody dry white wine finish.
Bottle from Mane Liquor. Very much like 3 Fonts Oude Geuze. Probably a touch funkier with some heavy lemon rind and zest. Very good as you would expect

Chilled green bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours clear golden with little white head.  Medium body, low carbonation, and sour aroma.  Taste is wonderful sour.  My favorite of the tasting, however Cascade Apricot was a close second.

Poured from a 375 ml bottle. Pours a copper color with a thin white head of foam. Aroma is fruity and sour with an earthy sweetness. Taste is that earthy sweet and sourness. Spritzy mouthfeel. Overall, very good.

Sample from 375ml bottle.

Hazy golden brown/orange, short white head.

Very dry funky acidic aroma with oak and acid, grapefruit and sour apples. The fruitiness is subdued compared to the funk and acidity. It almost gets a metallic vibe.

Taste is very sour with citrus, wood, pips and some vinegar. Very dry and puckering.

Medium+ bodied, with soft sparkling bubbles, light dry texture.

Its very tasty, but almost too aggressive.

Bottle.  Golden with big white head. Nose burning aroma, incredibly sharp musty funk. Taste is extremely sharp, lots of apple and funk. One of the sourest beers Ive had, draws in every part of the mouth, puckering, acidic. An exceptional gueze

2011/02/17 - Cork and Cage here - removing the cage brought the cork out on its own.Thats new. It wasnt a gusher - but the pour revealed something overcarbonated initial. The large head does finally dissipate, revealing a 1/2 finger white head that s fine bubbled, with modest lacing present. It retains well here. The pour is medium / dark gold that is modest cloudy - 

The nose is peppery, earthen oak, and lemongrass here. Theres a hint of vanilla, with musty notes prevalent. Its nice. The flavor profile reveals lively carbonation initial, moving to lemon zest, must, basement, bretty notes, with a sustaining bitterness. Pepper , Oak and earth, dried apricot, and a hint of sweetness here. This is a terrific brew for sure - Im assuming my carbonation issues arent the norm for this one. Naturally its a ridiculous price for the enjoyment level. I doubt Id buy this one again - but Ive got a few to age in the cellar.

375 ml bottle, big bang as i opened her. Pours hazy peach with huge tightly bubbled white head. Aromas of barn, wet wood, horse blanket, lemons, acidic fruit. Flavor is so vintage wooden with notes of haze, lemons, sour peach, and earthy citrus hops. Light to medium body with a good bit of carbonation. Finishes dry and long lasting. Doesnt get much better than this.
750ml Bottle - Amber in colour. Apricot, sultanas, damp leather and some musty notes in the aroma. Tangy, fruity and tart taste with notes of lemon, peach and apricot detected.

Thanks Grant!  Deep golden to orange in color.  Aroma of citrus, refined brett funk, leather, and light vanilla/oak.  Flavor is lemon citrus trailing to bright green apple.  Dries off nicely with subtle oak and vanilla.  Trailing citrus and leather, slightly bitter.  Moderately sour with nice complexity.  Light and crisp.

375ml bottle from IPB.
Appearance : Clear yellow with small head.

Aroma : Slightly mineral with acidic tart notes. Light barnyard, light hops. Nice wood. Wet socks.

Taste : Great citrusy tartness, light sourness. Great woody notes, light hops. Woody finish with tropical brett and other fruits. Persistent long finish.

Palate : Nicely soft but fizzy. Not aggressive.

Overall : Really nice one. Very well balanced and very elegant. Nice woody notes and nice hops. Quite smooth and polished (a bit like Girardin on that aspect). Nice light tropical fruits notes. Very fresh. For me this is better than the regular Oude Gueuze. Enough to pay the premium.

375ml bottle, 2011 vintage at Torst shared with jrgratz.  Pours a dark, clear gold with a medium foamy white head.  Aroma is of tart lemons with alot of musty funk and yeast notes. Taste is tart with notes of lemons and wood. Mouthfeel is delicate and beautiful balanced. Finish is smooth and tart. Terrific beer

Bouteille de 375 ml, bue côte à côte avec une 3F Oude Gueuze. Arômes assez complexes de veille cave et de brettanomyces. Robe orangée (légèrement plus foncée que celle de la Oude Gueuze), et trouble, peu de mousse et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, on retrouve un caractère de vieux lambic assez fort, avec des notes terreuses et poussiéreuses de vieille cave. Présence assez marquée de pediococcus (fromage, petits pieds). Le niveau dacidité, surtout lactique, est comparable à celui de la Oude Gueuze. Longue finale sèche et acide. Très bon, mais je préfère personnellement la fraîcheur citronnée de la Oude Gueuze régulière.

Bottle.

Hazy golden with a small white head. Nice tart aroma of citrus, wood and grape. The taste was very refreshing and nicely sour. Vinegar, wood, citrus and grape. Rather soft in a nice way.

Bottle from awlcordell. Thanks! Pours like a geueze. Deeply golden with a billowy white head. The nose is fantastic. rich grain, wheat, barnyard funk and horseblanket, all that jazz. Tart preserved lemon and earthy. I could smell this for hours. On tasting, it is sweeter than expected. I think the older lambic has concentrated resulting in a bit more body and graininess. Good high level of acidity, a bit bigger bodied. Super clean but the sweetness detracts a bit. Nice show overall.

(37,5 cl bottle from Toft Vin) Pours a sparkling, clear golden with medium, white head. Beautiful lace and decent retention as well as regeneration. Aroma is barnyard and cider. Oily texture, dry and tart finish. Taste is mostly sour with very little sweetness. Still not my favourite style.
Great nose fizzy smelling. Like champagne drinks better after sitting a bit.

Bottle, poured in a flute. Pours a hazy amber color with a moderate white head. Nose is slightly sour with a hint of wood in there. Taste is extremely sour and acidic with citrus notes. Easy and fun drink once you get past the acidity.
Golden amber with a nice big fizzy white head. Aroma is quite powerful of barnyard, dust, oak, green apple and lemon.  Very tart green apple flavour, some funk, some woodiness. Really nice.

375ml bottle.
Pours a hazy medium orange, with a white head.
Huge, complex, funky aroma, citrus, Brett, horse blanket, straw, phenols, earth, dried apples.
Bone dry, medium body, low bitterness, lively CO2.
Complex, funky taste, brett, citrus, markedly acidic, cider apples, earth.
Just great. (2013-03-12)
375ml bottle pours golden with a thin cream colored head with great retention. Nose of horsehair and farm animals. Taste is puckering and acidic. Mouthfeel is prickly.
Fairly orange golden color.  Aroma is tart, spicy, and wheaty.  Taste is tart, very wheaty, funky, nice.  Very nice gueze.

375ml bottle $24.99 (whoa). Poured this into a Drie Fonteinen geuze tumbler and it took forever. Not only did the cork almost rocket out but the head was unstoppable and even with a slow pour took forever, probably because I refuse to allow any of the sediment into my glass. Now I am going to jump ahead and say that this is a fantastic geuze overall but I probably wont buy any more unless I can slip it into an overseas order. Its great its just not light years ahead of the regular oude geuze. The appearance was beautiful, thick orange, milkshake fluffy head, perfect glassware. The aroma is pretty great, quintessential geuze, wheat, sour orange slices, maybe the slightest bit of oak, honey. Flavor is pretty fucking good, very round and mildly fatty, does not make me pucker at all. Grass, pepper, very tame lemon flavor, this is pretty exquisite. As I move through the glass I can admit that yes, this is better than the normal 3F geuze in the same way that the Oude Geuze Vintage and Armand 4 series are better. Masterful stuff. Beautiful geuze.

Serving type: bottle

12-25-2012 06:04:21

I was expecting a bit more from a brewery like 3F. This is a passable geuze though not up to the level of others. Maybe it was a bad bottle but I am a bit indifferent about this one. Thanks to tastybeer for sharing regardless. A new lambic is always worth sampling.

Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy golden body was partially a result of agitation. A rusty white head sits on top like dusty snowcaps. Carbonation is so active it looks like soda water with a dash of food coloring. Mineral water and polished gold give the high notes of a sour tang. This is certainly acidic but not as sharp as I expect a Belgian sour to be.

Flavor / Palate - The lemony taste is on the mark. Along for the ride are orange peels, which do not feel as crisp as I wanted them to. This is more sour than most beers but because of such high expectations falls short in the end. The problem comes with the price tag. At close to $20 a pop I can choose many other things in its place.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a huge white head. Aroma of oak, funk, citrus and straw. Taste is tart, citrusy with oak and a lot of funk. Really good, very sour with a lot of funk and oak. So drinkable and so sour, I love this one

Deep golden peach. Aroma is funk. Taste is citrus tart, astringent, soft funk. Yum. Tastier than the basic oude gueze. Fuller flavours as it warms - wood, funk. Palate - lingering tartness. Overall, great gueze; more satisfying to drink than the basic oude gueze. A fantastic balance between the crazy tart/sour and sweet.
Perfekt. Man blir ju nästan lycklig av en så fantastisk suring. Oerhört balanserad på alla parametrar.

Bottle, 2011 ed. Pour is hazy gold, white head. good retention/no lace. Aroma of barrel, dust, lacto, lemon. Taste is tart, dusty, barrel, mineral, lemon, attic. Palate is high carbonation, tart finish.
Dark gold, lively carbonation. Clean, crisp, refreshing. YEs, there is vinegar, lemon and rotting leaves in here, in addition to serious drinkability. Youll love or hate this.

Bottle. Pours dark golden, with a massive creamy head. Aroma is brett and oak, as well as nuts and lots of sour fruitiness from apples and rhubarb. Nice, long sour finish.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2014 Bottle 02/2011. Shared with Mathieu87.

2/21/13. Bottle during RBWG - thanks deftim13! Lightly hazed golden pour with a big frothy off-white head that sticks and laces plenty. Awesome aroma and flavor with a balanced dose of tart, wood, acid, and a touch of vanilla/cream with more lingering tartness. Delish!

Bottle from a trade for my 500th rate! 2/17/2011 bottle. Pours deep, hazy gold without much carbonation and only a slight head. No lacing. Strong, funky tart aroma of farmhouse and sweet tarts. Taste is surprisingly light. A nice tartness without being puckering. Very crisp and refreshing. Trying to sip and savor, but its tough!
Thanks to Danny at RBWG. Great frothy head. Aroma of funk. Tart but smooth throughout. Quite a nice gueze.

375 ml. bottle.  It does blow the cork!  Pours a cloudy light gold with a large white head.  Aroma of grass, citrus, and funk.  Taste is citrus, apples, funk, wood, and yeast.  Sour finish.  Very complex, very good.

Bottle. Cork flew. Rose gold with a white head that fades to a coat. Aroma of old lemons, tart berries, apples, sweaty hay. Slippery creamy texture with high carbonation - a bit excessive. Sour with berries, wheat and some peach, lots of lemon. Zingy bretty finish, sourness departs without much astringency remaining at the end.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2014 bottle at colins ... golden ... small white head ... soft horse blanket ... big funky tartness ... very dry funk ... way  to dry ... bnot me .. bttle at the bow ... soft funky orange nose...tart funky sour ... light lemon bottle at home ... goldne amber .. thin white lacing ... soft deep blanket .. light funk nose ... tart fruits ... earth funk .. soft mellow fruits ... light sour ... very dry ... 3.2

Bouteille verte de 375 ml, avec bouchon de liège, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de fleur avec une pointe citronnée. Apparence: La couleur est dorée-orangée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. rating from long-time-lost papers. 

i drank lh12, i drank zwanze 12 and 13 ( hel yeah) i drank some armand 4, i drank mavasia rosso, ... and i enjoyed them . this is why. before this bottle, i did not like any sour beer , at all. i can only thank 77 ships for turning me into a poor fuck with a basement full of geuzes :p 

much carbo, fast fading but very big foam. smell is very sour, but very balanced. even got some sweetness in the taste , very very good, very nice mouthfeel. want to be converted? drink this. want to keep some money ? AVOID :p
Le lambic 4 ans rajoute un goût de plus, qui fait du bien dans la yeule. Un excellent goût !

Bottle - thanks MikeB for sharing. Pours clear orange with a small off-white head and a bit of lacing. Aroma is light funk, citrus, lemon, some acetone, more - quite complex actually. Flavor is quite nice, light to medium tart and quite dry, almost sherry-like, with a bit of wood. Light bodied, somewhat prickly mouthfeel. Definitely the most complex gueuze I have tried.

Clear orange, light foam dissipates fairly quickly. Fragrant, fruity citrus smell with notes of the oak aging. Dry body, sherry like, a little funk but it is subdued. It comes through stronger as the glass warms. Oakiness in the finish. Only 6% ABV, but this drinks like an aperitif. Excellent.

Bouteille de 375 ml avec bouchon de liège. Mise en bouteille le 17/02/2011. Gueuze dorée foncée un peu trouble avec une mousse blanche. Le nez est boisé, sauvage à souhait, il y a une signature 3 Fontaines avec les notes dhuile de sésame, quon a retrouvé dans les 4 saisons dArmand. La bouche est ronde, boisée, acide mais pas trop, astringente en fin de bouche. Des tanins ?  Un prix de fou pour un produit dexception. Maintenant il ne me reste  quà lire la poésie de Gauvreau.

Un liquide mis en bouteille le 17 juillet 2011.  Une robe dorée et finement voilée.  Une tête mousseuse élégante qui cherche léternité.  Un nez très affirmé.  Des fleurs, des bactéries, des notes boisées et des notes citronnées tordantes.  Un fond de craquelin de sésame et de blé.  Des saveurs qui secouent mes papilles.  Des rafales de notes aigres portées par une intelligence suprême.  Des microbes et des bactéries sur des notes boisées vives.  Du foin et dautres choses qui relèvent dun mystère insaisissable.  Une bouche complètement sèche.  Une effervescence soutenue et délicate.  Des milliards de bulles si cela est possible.  Une finale complexe, surette et aigre, qui assure le bonheur des tissus de ma langue.  Quelque fois, boire un lambic cest comme lire la poésie de Gauvreau : rien nest à comprendre et tout est à saisir.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 So excited to try this!  Golden tangerine pour...some peach and honey as well.  The beer opened with a pop and left with a massive ivory cap.  Lemon-filled aroma with a sour, tart, pungent citrus pith nose.  Bright, grassy, dusty.  Flavor woke me up...like smelling salts.  Truly enjoyable...yum!

Oddly enough a Belmont bottle from right here in Ohio. Big time carbonation blew the cork out of the bottle but thank goodness it didnt overflow. Golden color which seems appropriate for the name. Huge tart/sour aroma but balanced with a hint of sugar rounds it out. Wow, thats fairly potent taste but it quickly mellows. Im not a huge Lambic geuze fan but this was nice

375ml bottle. Slightly hazy amber with an off white head that fades. Fairly sour with a nice funk, grass, lemon, dry. Full body, very dry moderate carbonation, sour, funky, hint of sweetness on the finish that eventually overwhelms. Like this but think it needs a bit more time.

I liked this one quite a bit.  Its got a nice combination of funky flavors that I look for in this style.  Good stuff.  Im glad I got try it.

Bottle.  Big pop of the cork.  Huge frothy gushing white head.  Deep golden yellow pour.  Big lemon zest, brett, and foggy wood aromas.  Not overly tart or sour, with reserved lemon, tangerine, and other assorted citrus flavors.  Highlights of brett, lowlights of damp wood.  Slightly acidic. Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Cloudy dirty yellow/orange-brown body, thin off-white ring. Wheaty, grassy nose, tart and lactic, with noes of lemon and sharp, dusty wood. Dry, tart body with lemon pulp, dust, and cobwebs, grassy. Light, dry, and tart but not too sour. Expectedly excellent.

Bottle at t Antwaerps Bierhuiske (Antwerp, Belgium)
Aroma: Brett, lemon, basement aromas

I had been looking forward to trying this one for a while and am very happy that I finally had the chance. That said, the price is a little exaggerated considering its not a big step up from the Oude Geuze.

$22.00/375 ml green bottle. Hazy golden with a small head. The aroma is spicy, and sour. It also has aromas of lemons, green apples, and bubblegum. Its really smooth and almost delicate. The taste has more lemons with a sharp acidic middle. There is also a funkiness that shows itself more as the beer warms. Its well carbonated with a sparkly mouthfeel and finishes with an oaky dryness. A very good geuze and I like the concept. Although I would reach for a more affordable option of a comparable tasting gueze when given the chance.

Bottle. Pours a very hazy golden orange with huge slightly offwhite head. Took forever to get it into the glass. Aromas are dominated by sweet sour apples, lots of burnt rubber like funk and sharp lemony acidity. Slightly bitter taste with plenty of lemony acidity to finish. Medium mouthfeel.

Bottle. Yellow, light orange with sediment, good carbonation. Nose has malts, sour apple, funk, horseys. Body is sharp, acidic, with some vinous tones. The funk is soft and mellow, but strongly present, old like a good horsey wine (e.g. cht. musar). A bit mouth drying and sharp on the fruityness, otherwise perfect.-- bb/h

Elle est dorée, voilée et coiffée dune mousse impeccable, qui se résorbe lentement en lui laissant une dentelle écumeuse aux parois. Odeurs très agréables, on sent la levure sauvage, des fruits acidulés, comme le fruit de la passion, de pommes surettes et certaines sortes doranges, dans un assortiment de bois franc et de bois vert. La palette des saveurs est fidèle aux arômes. Lacidité est très prononcée et sempare, littéralement, de toutes les papilles gustatives. Bottle: Poured a hazy golden color lambic with a large foamy head with great retention and some excellent lacing. Aroma of light funk with some tart green apple notes. Taste is a complex and refreshing at the same time mix between some funk and green apple notes with light tart finish. Acidity level if so well balanced. Body is quite full with super great carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very well brewed and super enjoyable and also somewhat reminiscent of Girardin gueuze. .

Bottle. Pours a cloudy earthy gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a lot of sour fruit with a nice earthy funk and a hint of acid. Flavor starts with strong acidic fruit that mellow to a nice sourness that is backed by funk throughout.

Very aromatic Gueuze, with more Brett notes than Im used to from 3F, smelling from a whole meter away as soon as the bottle is popped open. Hard to pour with its extremely vivacious carbonation that generates an eternal white tower atop the bubbly gold. Intense lemon aromas in which the wheat comes across neatly, adding an oily feel to this otherwise bone-dry offering. Extremely attenuated, yet not overly thin. Its bubbles deserve some time to settle down a bit because it feels rougher than what this producer usually delivers in terms of mouthfeel elegance. Champaign-like indeed, including the earthy, salt cracker and nutty rancio notes. In mouth, its acidity is very serious, adding a soft acetic suggestion to the lactic and citric showdown. A beer could be blended with citrus juice, it would not get much more citrusy than this. And in the second half, a surprisingly salty attack joins the parade and seemingly dry the beer out farther. It is pretty good stuff, but I miss the ironically exuberant elegance of what I feel are the very top notch 3 Fonteinen. It makes for a rougher, less drinkable drink that yet remains very refreshing.

Extremely bubbly … with lots and lots of suds. Almost like a champaign. The aroma is awesome with citrus and wheat; very intense. Taste is bitter and quite dry; this is not a style I'm used to but it is good. It's tart but subtle and the notes of oak blend very well.  Not a go-to style for me but I appreciate its uniqueness.

bottle shared for xmas with some of the beer buddies after a day of brewing. this is sour then funk and wonderful as well as expected. the appearance is a wonderful orange with a ring of pearl white bubbles. the taste is of sour yet mellow sour bite, bits of sour lemon and citrus. the body is light and full of life and carbonation. very dry finish that leaves you salivating for the next sip. overall this is a bit pricey but worth trying at least once and possibly to see how it cellars.
Bottle. Aromas of spice, sour fruit, and musk. Cloudy golf, light head. Sharp acidity up front smooths into a soft muskiness. Finish is underripe strawberries and funk.

Bottled sample. Gold in colour with a bit of haze and strong spritzy carbonation. Typical 3F aromas of dried wooden barrel, lemon peel and funk, along with a faint floral note. Flavors are of driftwood, lemon, white pepper, funk, and more delicate florals. Light bodied with firm sourness and acidity. Great complexity and potency.
Bottle. Golden color with an off white head. Manure, funky, barnyard, woody, and fruity. Nice sour finish.

375mL bottle, pours a cloudy orange with a large white head. Nose is super funky, full of horse blanket, barnyard funk and spice. Flavour is super wild and funky, with loads of barnyard funk, horse blanket, lots of yeast and again a hint of spicings. Extremely funky and wild, with a very high but fitting carbonation. So highly drinkable with that classic gueuze wildness and funky. One of the best gueuzes out there.

Hazy golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of Brett, wood, bacteria, hay, candy apple, and musty cellar. Taste of hay, citrus, funk, Brett, bacteria, and a sour finish.

Pours hazy orange in color with an off white head. Wow - the aroma is a whole different level with some unique funk and pleasant sweet candy tartness so nice in the nose. The flavor is more sweet and sour than funky, with some pleasant tartness that ends on the palate quite nicely. The 4 year old blend with the other years has worked out deliciously!

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2013 (Fév. 2011): Esthétiquement parfaite, cuivrée avec une dentelle mousseuse alléchante. Au nez, beaucoup de complexité et de maturité, du bois et de lacide lactique à la pelle. La chlorophylle est aussi très ancrée, très surette et sèche en fin de bouche. Lincorporation, dans le mélange, dun lambic de 4 ans donne vraiment une dimension intéressante.

12.7 ml bottle, dated 2/17/11. from Binnys DG.  At 25 bucks, tied with BADL for the most Ive paid for a beer by volume.  But I knew it might be my only chance.  Started untwisting the wire around the wire and the cork started moving.  Highly carbonated and pressureized.  Poured into snifter very gently still gave over 1 finger of clean white head.  Clear golden in color.    Very tart and sour.  Lemon and citrius.  Flavor is so strong you need to sip slowl.  As far as unflavored sours/lambics/berlinerweise this tastes the same as the others ive tried.

375ml bottle purchased at west lakeview.  bottling date of 12/17/2011. second occasion having been able to try this.  the first was with the owner of novare res who is one stand up guy but i digress... cork opens with a pop, there was some pressure built up behind there.  the pour yields a hazy orange, semi-translucent, apricot colored composition allowing for a little light penetration while topped with a heafty soapy white head that took a few minutes to settle down before being able to top off... aroma is musty with that genuine geueze like horseblanket nose. accents of lemon and hay throughout.  not sure why theres a tendency for me to use lemon as a descriptor but i think the idea gets across as a citrus like basement sourness.  somewhat sharp and cheesy in just the right way... flavors dont let up much from the what the aroma had to offer.  sharp semi-acidic musty horseblanket upfront, lemon and hay that collide or shall i say meshing with lively dry carbonation that adds a prickly sensation to the tongue.  rather tart overall and just the way it should be, in my opinion which fades and ultimately leaves an earthy dryness on the sides of the mouth.  easy to drink and leaves you wanting to grasp for more.  should probably do a side by side with the regular geueze to discern more similarities or disimilarities but at this pricepoint,  this cant be regular habit of mine although i with that it could be.  splendid.

375 ml bottle. Deep golden colour. Crystal clear. Cork pops when bottle opened. Very high carbonation level that leaves a thick coarse head, which falls down quickly leaving only a small thin lace. Intense sour nose with peaches and lactic acid. Clean aroma. Sharp sour flavours, but with a nice mellow soft maltiness. Hints of oak and oranges. Dry finish. The funk show up towards the finish. A very nice geuze. Very drinkable, surprisingly clean, and very nice.
Projectile cork. Not worth the high price it sells for but fat pour I had of it was delicious. Super carbed but a nice tart lemony taste that seemed to have 50 layers.

375ml Bottle at UDRBM. Just slightly hazy copper golden colour, white head. Aroma of sour lemons, flowers, a hint of cat piss on a conifer, wood. Flavour is sour, lemons, refreshing acidic sourness in the finish, wood. Light-bodied. I was expecting to seriously down-rate this beer, but it was way better than anticipated. Simple, fresh and straightforward gueuze, nothing complex.

12.7oz bottle, purchased at City Beer. Pours a bright, clear, deep-deep golden color; fine-bubbled white head with excellent retention and lacing. Dense, salty, funky nose: lots of salt upfront, lemony tartness and vibrant acidity and a restrained dose of funk: pinpoint, salty, lemony, mouthwatering lambic. Medium body; effervescent; forward acidity and plenty of funk and tartness; the core focus here is a focused lemony acidity and tartness coupled to a funky and highly salty framework; the salinitys a bit more amplified here than in some of their other limited-release lambics, and this doesnt quite match up to some of the Armand releases in terms of drinkability and layered qualities, but a damn fine salty and assertive lambic; touches of soft oak around the perimeter. Lasting finish of tart citrus rind and light emergent toastiness.
Golden clear body and thin white bubbly lace. Apple, wood, funky and refined. Active body, dry palate, lemons.  Not complex but nice sourness. Nice, excellent aroma. (UDRBM)
Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is sharp and tart cherry with green apple, basement and some spices. Flavour is dry sourness, big fruits, green apple dominating, some barn. Nice one

Bottle at UDRBM. Hazy golden pour. Aroma of typical geuze with horse blanket and wet cellar. Quite spicy and lively. Flavor is sour, spicy and well balanced. Not bad, but still more of the same from 3F.
375 ml from Shenanigans. Tart and lambic all the way. Slightly dusty and oaky. Bit of peach. Really nice.

375 ml bottle from Binnys SL (Chicago, IL). Opened as a Post Boxing Up 5 Trades Treat. Pours a richer deep golden amber hue, darkness in the body, good haze, and some deeper amber glow throughout. A huge head is offwhite, laces well, sticks around firmly. Well carbonated as the cork pops immediately upon uncaging but doesnt gush. Aromas are a rich melange of sour fruit, lemon and melon, oranges and crab apple. Gentle pear, straw, and doughy bread. Lactic lemony and yogurty sourness, some sweet tarts, firm funkiness grows, horseblanket, straw, and gentle cobwebs. A kiss of leather, richer oak presence on the nostrils as some bigger fruit elements, firmly sour, keep me quite interested. As it settles more funk comes forward, but still Id call it a richer firmly sour fruit presence, moving into a more funky dry backend on the nose. Initial is quite nice, dry and a bit earthy up front, lively carnonation on the palate, gentle crab apple and pear, melon, sour lemons and gentle bready dough. Lactic yogurt, lemony sourness, and more fruit, bigger melon and crab apple feel at times. Firmly sour, but not overwhelming at all, the middle shows more yogurt, straw, and dough. Sweeter fruit elements make their case here, melon and apple, pear, kiss of honeysuckle and white wine. Dough, gentle spice. Backend gets a bit more tart again, more funk and cobwebs, horseblanket, grass, and straw. Gentle sweat, cobwebs, and dry funky brett. A touch of saddle, the funk only comes on into the backend and finish, the nose leads you to believe there would be a bit more. Lingering sour lemon, melon, and apple.. Gentle dough, firm yogurt and straw, dryness and funk. The oak in this beer comes and goes, mellow then a bit more firm, dying out a bit more but coupling with the dry stages well. Overall, when compared to the regular Oude, its a bit more vibrant, sour and fruity elements give some nice complexity and make it a touch more special for me. Finish is dry and tart, lactic and funky. Dry and mellow, with lingering touches of fruit, sourness, and gentle yet inviting funk. Quite a nice beer, if I say so. Id like to buy a few to put away if I just had $100 laying around. With that said, everyone who likes Lambic and Sour beer should try it.

Cork shot out when unwinding the cap and missed Ernestos eye by about 1 inch and slammed on the ceiling.  Aroma is ridiculously good with nice funk and vanilla, pineapple, lemon, a little musty barnyard.  Taste is nicely tart up front with huge barrel character with notes of vanilla and coconut to go with the heavy tart citrus fruits.  AMAZING.
Wow this is very impressive, pineapple coconut and vanilla, subdue tartness with complex body and dry crisp fizzy finish

375ml bottle from West Lakeview.  Pours a golden amber color with a big, fluffy white head.  Aroma is lemon, musty, funky, oak.  Medium on the palate with lively carbonation. UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 Bottle.  Hazy dark gold, white head.  Awesome aroma, hay, funk, leather, musty grain.  Nice sour flavor, lemon grass, dirty hay, light old sock, sweetness, and a tart finish.  I need to drink gueuze more often, but its expensive.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of doodler to celebrate Obamas re-election. Thanks so much Scott! Pours a cloudy orange appearance with a somewhat small, cream colored head. Its more and more noticeable how much more this burns on the finish now than when I first tried it. Not that that is a bad thing, its just not what I am used to with 3 Fonteinen.
Bottle shared by a friend. Clear gold pour with a medium off-white head. Sour and peppery nose with some malt. Malty flavor with peppery yeast and a sour lemon finish.

Aroma:  Gorgeous aroma, smells of sour yeast, apples (definitely most powerful aroma), strong white grapes and maybe some oak.  Appearance:  Perfect orange aroma, white head with nice lacing.  Taste:  Immediate sour flavor with some hoppy strange bitterness at the end, the apple from the aroma doesnt show through, grapes do though, almost rivals a Champagne in dryness. Overall:  Sours and especially oude geuze are not usually my favorites, but this is a special one, 3 fonteinen doesnt come around everyday.  Excellent beer that screams complexity, dont try if you are unworthy.

(From notes 3 Nov, 2012) Bottle. Airy white/orange head. Fizzy foam that settles quickly. Orange gold, clear beer. Aroma is oaky, sourness, slight caramel (?), maybe some apple (though this might be an association with oak). Overall, refreshing aroma. Tastes sour, bitter and a wee bit acidic. Carbonation is very high, causing stingyness on the palate. Finish is very dry and pretty short.Giving gueuzes a shot. 3 Fonteinen Oude Geuze Golden Blend was challenging. Maybe some day...

Bottle from Vika enjoyed at home
Opens with a BAM! Luckily not a gusher. Pours copper hazy with a white head. Smells of barnyard, funk, musty brett and some malts. Light sweet, a wall of sourness, heavy sour, nice and dry, lots of yeast flavors and by that i mean brett. Some hints of bitterness. A very nice gueuze. 3 Fonteinen really is the master of gueuze in my eyes. A very nice blended one, and i hope to try it again some time

Bottle shared by Ludvig. 

Looks very beautifull i had very high hopes on this one. Unfortunally it did not really reach those hights still a very good geuze.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2014 Bottle (375 ml). Beautiful and almost clear golden with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma of apple, wood, fruits, leather and funky notes. Taste is of wood, fruits, leather with a nice sourness. Very smooth gueuze and one that I would drink on a regular basis if it was not of the price. Still quite smooth... tastier than the last bottle I had and it definitely gained some depth and complexity. Bottle purchased from The Bottle Shop in Brugge, flown back to the states & shared with some bros. 

Pours a golden color with a small but well retained head. 

The aroma is remarkably funky & dusty. Some horse sweat, some limestone, and some nice lemony character. Everything is well integrated, everything is pungent, but nothing is rude or out of place. 

The flavor is very lemony, nicely sour... perhaps on the higher end of sour, particularly for 3 Fonteinen. A nice fruitiness, some rind (both the cheese and citrus kind). The flavor is earthy a little briny, complex, and well woven together. The depth of flavor, and the pungency of the flavors in this are remarkable but the lambic is so carefully blended that everything works pleasantly and in its own way. 

The palate is sharp, and bubbly interesting, & not overly prickly... if Gueuze is supposed to be as bubbly as Champagne then this falls short, but it doesnt matter a bit the mouthfeel works perfectly well to carry the flavors of this beer, I dont know that I would want it more bubbly than it is.

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream head. Sour and tart aroma with oak and light woodsiness. Sour/tart flavor with earth and oak. Medium bodied. Dry finnish. Sour/tartness lingers with oak and light fruitiness.
