Flavor consisted of lemon flesh, citrus pith, lemon and grapefruit zest seemlessly integrated with the damp basement, cob web, leather, horse blanket and pungent parmesan cheese.  Light body with high tongue prickling carbonation.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Great geuze, but 26 bucks for a 375ml will prevent me from buying this again.

Big big props to my buddy Kyle for sending me this gem. You rock brotha! Open with caution! The top popped right off before I even took the cage off. Luckily I was able to save everything inside, didnt miss a drop. Incredible balance between sour fruit and tartness. One I wish we had on the shelves in FL.
bottle... another solid drie but the prices are out of hand for something not significantly different than a regular oude gueuze
2012.10.21 - bottle 37.5cl - golden orange, big white head -  nose : is tart, oak, green apple - mouth : dry tartness, oak, green apple.
Bottle 375ml from erzbierschof. Complex with lemon peel and horse blanket throughout. Some dandelion in the finish. Excellent, top notch gueuze.

Courtesy of Vendomebh1 via trade
Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate lemon, lighter sweet citrus notes, cheese, and faint barnyard. The cork exploded out of the bottle as soon as the cage was removed. It pours a hazy golden-orange with a two finger lightly orange tinged off-white head with pretty good retention. The flavor starts with a quick dose citrus. The finish is moderate sour lemon, light oak, funk, and just a hint of cheese. Its light bodied with lively carbonation, but it manages to come across as somewhat soft. Really good stuff.

Pours golden with a small white head. Aroma is tart and sour wit oak, cheese, funk, green grapes, barnyard. Taste is well balanced, nice sourness witout going over the top, barnyard, oak, dusty, funky, grapes, cheese. Thin body, lively carbonation, dry finish. Lovely.

pour is slightly hazed dark golden orange with a tight light tan head.  The nose has tons of cheese, rather "rindy," and a light dusty funk behind.  Golden fruits, apricot, pear, and peach. A light vinegar note underneath. The taste is slightly more muted than the nose, the funk isnt as bright but still an assertive cheese rind with more cob webby funk. The apricot and golden fruits are intertwined very well. The finish is dry and well carbonated, the body is light and bubbly on the tongue.

Dejlig syrlig. Smagt på Lord Nelson. God aroma. Ligner en øl, men smager meget meget mere

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
tasty beer, i hope it will get better with age! because i hoped for it a bit too much, still its good.

Bottle at Stockholm Beer and Whiskey Festival 2012. Hazy golden/yellow liquid with medium white head. Aroma of 3F funk (barnyard, sweat, leather), lemons and apples. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of barnyard, apples and lemons. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Really nice, considerably more sour than the regular blend.

375 ml bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a ton of carbonation and huge head. Cork popped out of the bottle as soon as the cage was off... Sour aroma with notes of wood barrels, lemons, and peaches. A perfect blend. Sour but not overly so. A mix of flavors: Ripe stoned fruit, citrus, light wood, and plum skins. Excellent.

Golden (!) with a small diminishing head. Aroma is of classic gueuze. Taste/flavor got that extra sour kick but it might be just me associating the 4yr old lambic. Overall a really refined gueuze from a master blender!

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012 Bottle at ginger man with Andrew and Brendan. Pours a deep hazy orange golden body with thick white lacing. Aroma is lemon, thick Brett, oak and funk. Mouthfeel is medium, creamy and delicate. Notes of lemon meringue and funky wood. Amazing and delicate.
Cloudy yellow orange with a small pale head. Aroma is funk, lemon juice, sour fruits. Refreshing on the palate, very well balanced. Taste is apricot, pear, sour plum. Nice blend!

333 c&c from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours bright orange gold with an off-white head. Nice earthy sour aroma. Med + body. Flavor is tart, arthy sour. Very smooth; delicate. Arguably a citrus note. Delicious.

Bottle generously shared by bhensonb. Pours dark golden with a modest off-white head and a sour barnyard aroma. There is a delicate sour fruit and funk flavor that represents a near-perfect blend of aged gueuze (probably due to the addition of 4 year). Very nicely done.

from Erzbierschof - coudy dark blond beer under a long lasting foam; solid cheesy aroma with notes of apples and vinegar; creamy palate and fairly carbonated; medium-bodied and with a solid sourness/acidity; very dry and long fruity and cheesy finish with a lingering acidity
Bottled at SBWF.  Hazy pale golden, small head. Citric, intense barnyard aroma. Tart and mildly acteic. Juicy and freshening, some cobwebs and barnyard. Light vinegar and stale hop bitterness.

12 oz. bottle. It pours an orange gold color, slightly darker than the oude geuze, with a nice fluffy white head. The aroma is over the top with citrusy fruit; lemon, tangerine, grapefruit, hay and some salty leather and underlying notes of oak. More hay, less funk and much brighter citrus notes than the regular oude geuze. The flavor is down right sublime with bright notes of grapefruit rind, tangerine, subtle oak and soft but complex acidity that feels luxurious on the palate. The mouthfeel is where this really shines above the rest for me. So soft and refined which I imagine comes from the 4 year old lambic. It really showcases the flavors perfectly.  Probably the best lambic Ive ever had.

Bottled on 2011/02/17. 375 ml bottle into a tulip glass. As soon as I started to unscrew the cage I felt the cork lift up. After some wrangling around with a towel I removed it safely. 

A - Clear dark amber body. Tons of off white foam after the initial pour, settles down into a neat one finger high head with some large bubbles. Lots of rising carbonation. Great lacing and retention. I rarely give out 5s on appearance, but it just looks damn perfect.

S - Balance is the one word that comes to mind. Earthy brett funk, lemon rind, sour green apples, rubber bands, and oak barrel. Its all very intense and concentrated, but its just so well integrated.

T - More of that great balance. Earthy funk, cheese, vinegar, oak, sour lemons, and some light vanilla tannins. Incredibly complex and layered. This gueuze is beyond delicious. The finish is dry and abrupt with only a lingering lactic presence. Mouth feel is spritzy and well carbonated. 

O - Armand can blend some of the best gueuzes out there, and this one ranks right up there. I havent had the opportunity to try the season beers, but the standard oude gueuze is my favorite beer and this totally beats it. That fourth year is a beautiful thing which makes the $30 hit seem worth it.

Bottle shared at Sante Adairius. Opens with a substantial "pop" but no gushing as in other reviews. Pours a yellow-gold color with a nice white head. Really lovely aroma, oranges and grapefruits and light floral notes, chlorine and basement. Lactic sourness, citrus rind, dust, grass, wet wood. Really sublime in its balance. Great blend.
@ Basunen: En mycket len syrlig doft. Smaken består av tydliga vindruvor och äpplen. Trevlig syrlighet som river gott.

375 ml. bottle split by 4. Procured @ Hopduvel. Man this baby is carbonated, luckily that I anticipated this. Once i loosened the cage a bit, the cork began moving upwards, I had to forsibly hold it down so that it wouldnt hit the ceiling, first time that this happened to me honestly but still no gusher. I tried pouring slowly but I still got pretty much a full glass of mousse-like fluffy head and very little in the way of beer. Slowly the head began collapsing forming mountains. The beer itself is a very hazy, murky orange. Smell is huge horse-blanket funk with plenty of old 3F in there with some of that neat earthly mushroom thing going on, lots of this tad earthly citrus, some minor fruitiness and cleaner wood. Taste clearly carries quite a bit of that old 3F mushroom funk, tad lessened by the newer a bit less awesome old blend that they use, lots of horse-blanket, murky, some earthly citrus and tad earthly tangerines, as usual not much in the way of vinegar, wood and lightly burned caramel. Murky, hazy body with nice carbonation. This is more in the trend of just an older 3F geuze - like that is a bad thing. Awesome like any    blend that Armand makes - he is just that good. I do prefer a bit the clearness and brett-ness of young one more for everyday drinking and its easier for the wallet as well. It is a steep price but you do get more or less what you paid for, might have been a tad cheaper but ok. Hope that he is now finally out of the 4 yr old 3F lambic because frankly the amount of beers made with it are suspicious. I do not agree with the people who told to me that this is either too young to drink or that it tastes exactly the same as a regular one but that might be just my pallet.
Pours lighted golden with a trim thin head. Smells of tart, pineapple, asparagus, candle and brett. Tastes the same.

Big white head shrinks with a fizzing sound.  Slightly hazy
golden body with carbonation.  Deep horsey earthy aroma with
funky strawy fruity notes.  Dry-acidic earthy horsey taste with
vinegary wooden notes.  Mid-to-thin body.  Sharpish mouthfeel.
Dry wooden horsey aftertaste with fruity earth funky notes.  Its
a bit rough in flavour, somehow, and doesnt have quite enough
enjoyable parts.  Not their best, I think.  (0.375l bottle, wine
monopoly, Vika, Oslo.)

Bottle at Sour and Bitter 2012. Pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Sweet and tart with some bitterness and hints of vinegar. Aromas of pine and hints of grass, sweat and barnyard. Also some fruity aromas of apples. Medium bodied. Lively carbonation. Dry finish.

Bottle. Gold pour, very slight haze, white head. Aroma is quite woody, green pepper, oak, smells a bit old already. Just read that it contained 4 year old lambic, probably where that aged aroma comes from. Regular 3F funk, taste is sour, woody, a tad dryer than the regular oude gueuze. Palate is effervescent with full body. Might not quite be worth its price but very good indeed.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2013 I picked up 6 of these in Belgium in May. Have sent 2 away to friends and finally enjoying this myself and making a review. I dont have a gueuze glass so I am enjoying this at cellar temp (55 today) in a Riedel white wine glass. Bottle date, 11/02/2011. Best by 02/2021.

A - This is a GUSHER! The cage was just barely untwisted about 2 turns when the cork shoots and makes a dent in my ceiling. WOWOWOW! Gorgeous color. Bright golden orange with an insane amount of carbonation bubbles traveling from the bottom of the glass to the top. Looks like a champagne. I poured as slow as possible and the head was still 5 fingers. Very big pillow like solid white head with tight bubbles at the bottom and big puffy bubbles at the top. After 4 minutes, head was 3 fingers. Its dropping very slowly. Lacing is impossible to avoid. A single swirl returns me to 5 finger head. 

S - The smell is almost as great as Armand4 (Lente). Huge notes of grass, lemon juice and an incredible amount of hay. Hints of wheat as well and fresh cut grass. There is no hint at all of vinegar or cider. The very horseblanket and musty characters persist through the back of my throat via very excited nostrils. Wow!

T - Huge lemony taste up front. Like sucking on a freshly peeled lemon slice. Hint of very farmhouse style Belgian yeast. Theres absolutely no sweetness but a big oaky presence at the finish is very persistent and sticks around. It has this almost ball-park pretzel taste. Bready, chewy and hints of salt. Took me a while to pinpoint it. Utterly delicious and much softer than expected. Absolutely no harsh tastes in this gueuze.

M - Solid carbonation but nothing overpowering. Medium body which was surprising and this oak finish that I love matched so well with a tart bite.

O - I LOVE the 3 Fonteinen Lente. It was an amazing beer. I have but have not tried the other 3 Armand seasons nor have I had the coveted Millenium Geuze. However, this is by far my favorite Gueuze from the master-blender Armand. Im very happy to have many more of these and experience how it progresses over time. I will for sure be buying more!

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2014 Bottle in Craft Beer Co. Colour is clear golden, small white head. Nose is lemon, farmyard, grassy, hay, yeasty, musty. Taste is soft, sour, citrous lemon,  tart, grassy, grainy and bitter. nice balance between sour tartness and grassy malt character. Soft on palate. 3.9 Re-rate - bottle at home, bought at Dranken Pauwels. A very very deep amber golden. You cant see through it, but I wouldnt describe it as hazy. Nose is wonderful. Horse blanket, lots of funk, farmyard, lemon sherbet, sour lemons, white apple sour, Bramley sour, tart acidic. Nice sweets and sours. Taste is acidic, tart, crisp, lemon acidic and bitter, moderate tartness. Clean and crisp and minerally. An almost lemonade like character with more sour lemon and lime acidic. I like a bit more body and pucking punch in my lambics. Stays a 3.9

In bottle at The Cambridge Blue. Pours a golden amber colour with a fair white head. Aroma of wet cardboard, lemon, horse-blanket and caramel. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Nicely sharp and quite dry to finish.

Pours a golden orange into my 3 Fonteinen tumbler. Head is huge with amazing lacing. Pure white and lasts forever. Carbonation is very lively. Aromas are barnyard, oak, lemon and fresh cut grass. Sourness is all there. An amazing blend. Thank you Armand!!!

On 35 cl bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika,Oslo.
Golden color, ok foam.
Mediuma stable aromas
Medium body & high complexity.
Good sourness,some bitterness- good balance
Very enjoyable- one of the best Geuzes I tried

375ml bottle pours a golden orange color with a 2 and a half finger white bubbly head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is lemon with some yeasty notes.  Taste is sour lemons with some woodiness and yeast and mild underlying sweetness.  Highly carbonated with a medium body leaving a pleasant sensation on the palate.  A very well done lambic that is worthy of a sampling.

Bottle. A bit of dust or early leakage dried on the lip of the bottle. Dark amber with slight cloudy and thick noisy head. Salty edged Gueze aroma. Dry and lightly salty, a bit woody. Strong condensed flavour.

375mL shared by CanIHave4Beers. Smells awesome. Iodine. Oh man, this is quite sour and quite good. Strong, but soft, well rounded funk. Salty BO.

Pours cloudy amber with a white head. Aroma is acidic, grapefruit, leather and fruit. Flavour is acidic, tart, grapefruit, leather and sour notes.

37.5cl at home, brought by Olly. This was again loaded with Armands signature character that you find in all his vintage gueuzes! Earthy, musty, bacon, grain and a funky sourness. Well carbonated, golden hazy colour and big White head. This one was sampled a bit young for my liking but should be great to age! Wish the bottle size was bigger though.

37,5 cl bottle courtesy of Travlr. Botteldatum 17/02/2011.  The pour is hazed golden orange with a 2 inch foamy egg white head. Falls rocky with splotchy lacing. Streaking tiny bubbles fill the glass. The aroma is tart apple, soft woody earthiness, faint lemon citrus sour vinegar. Soft gentle nose. The taste is the citrus lemon sourness, followed closely by bright dry tartness, hay and grass, closes with wood and yeastiness. As it warms, get some of the acetic yeast that I associate with the 3 Fonteinen house character.  The palate is light bodied, fine active, champagne like carbonation, dry tart finish. Refreshing, easy drinking beer.  Very much appreciate the bottle Gene.

Bottled 375ml (bottled 02/2011, vPBF)
Deep golden color, small white head. Tart fruity, leathery lambic aroma. Medium-bodied. Tasty, tart, fruity flavor. Perhaps not so mouth-drying fruity as many lambics, more dry. Horseblanket, sherry, peach. Nice as always.

375 ml bottle @ vPBF 2012.
Pours a golden colour with loads of bubbles and a white head. Aroma of strong ripe apricot, earth and barnyard - classic Gueuze aroma. After that its tart fruitiness and ends aggressive, tingling, also very smooth and grapefruity. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. Quite complex and has aggressive. Yummy.

37,5 cl bottle @ vPBF, bottled 17.02.2011
Aroma is rather strong on earthy notes. Also some grapefruit. Flavour is rather sour with grapefruit, some orange, earthy and leathery notes. Dry finish with somewhat disturbing tartness. Rather good still.

375ml bottle @ vPBF

Pours orange with a small white head.
Aroma of earthy notes, sour and tart fruits, hints of oak and wood.
Taste is smooth and dry with some tart fruitiness and hints of sourness.
Finish is slightly sour and tart with some earthy notes. Well balanced, tasty and quite smooth geuze.

text: 375ml green corked and caged bottle. Clear bubbly gold, smallish fizzy offwhite head. Heavy sour aroma - lemon, funk - yummmm. Taste follows - fruity as hell. Oh just  awesome!

Pours an orangish brown color with an off white cap. The smell is tart fruit, lemon zest, oak, some funk. I hope that I can snag a few more of these before they are all snagged up!

Bottle. Thanks to Chris for this one. Pours a slightly cloudy orange amber color. Nice tight white head. Funky aroma, oaky, lemon zest. Light mouthfeel. Funky sour upfront that lingers on for a while. Lemon and sour apple notes. Slight drawn out bitterness. Complex. Very nice.
Bottle at CCB Day, Sätila 2012-07-07. Golden hazy beer with a offwhite small head. Citrus, sourish, vinous, leather, fruity aroma. Similar flavour with happy notes.

Pours "golden orange". Small white head. Beautiful! Fresh,citrusy, grassy aroma. The taste is incredibly fresh and young. Think good newly squeezed lemons... perfectly (and i mean it this time...) balanced with some old bitter hops! Yes it tastes as erotic as it sounds... Small touch of herbal funkiness...

Bottle.
Pours almoast solid orange without any head.
Fresh aroma of grass, flowers and some tartness.
Tart but balanced and smooth taste. Peachy fruityness.

Very stable, thcik & dense yellow head over veiled bright-orange beer. Woody, citrussy, horseblanket, leathersoap, but also flowery, hint @ vanilla. Very tart, ultra-dry, but yet frutiy/lemony; also woody, blank oak. Titillating acidity. Dry-out effect, over-attenuated, refreshing as none. Superbly balanced, yet ultra-dry gueuze. Golden indeed.

Bottle shared by that black ipa guy and once the his shitty ass pour of my beer settled out, I could see the orange haze of the beer and the glass full of foam had settled thin, but solid, for the most part...and of off-white hue.   Nose has interesting elements, elements of funk, elements of fermenting apples, layers of aging cheese, juicy grape elements, elements I tell you.  On to the elements of flavor:  still nice and funky, like slices of cheese melted over apples, sprinkled with some white pepper...elements of funk.  Elemental, I tell you.

Pours a hazy light orange with an obnoxious frothy head that doesnt go away. Nose is spicy, sharp tangy funk. Nice. Taste is crotch cheese, untreated genital warts and funk. Awesome. Finishes dry, tart and quick except for the lingering spicy notes which put this beer over the top for me. Well executed.

(Bottle, 0,375 l, at Tuulensuu, 20120811) The beer poured golden and quite clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had wood, sourness, vomit and malts. Palate was medium bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were wood, sourness, tartness, malts and very low bitterness. Aftertaste was woody, sour and tart. Wood presence and sourness were stronger than in the normal oude geuze. Still very good and balanced beer.

375ml cork and caged bottle.

Pours a clear golden amber with a surprisingly big beige head that sticks around with an abundance of bubbles feeding the bottom.

Aroma is earthy grasses and barnyard funk with some lemon zest and other citrus notes.  Plenty of oak and there is just a light mustiness to the whole thing.

Really earthy and musty up front with the citrus kicking in through the middle.  The finish is very dry and crisp.  There is also a bit of mineral character in the taste as well as oak and a light acidity.

Mouthfeel is light and very active on the palate with strong carbonation.

Another fantastic blend from Armand.  Cant wait to see how this one develops.  I wouldnt put it up there with Blauw or Lente, but its still a superb sour.

37,5cl bottle at Dr. Jekylls Pub, Oslo. Pours clear amber with a nice off-white head. Aroma of barnyard, citrus, horse blanket, brett and wood. Intense aroma with a delicious sourness. Dry, citric and very refreshing. Quite long and dry aftertaste. Excellent gueuze.
Hazy orange coloured beer with small white head and no carbonation. Sour fruited aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is medium sour with bitter hints. Nice one!

Bottle at home, from a Tilquin tumbler, as I do not yet have a 3 Fonteinen tumbler, but the Tilquin is VERY similar... Cork damn near took my eye out as soon as I took off the cage, though it wasnt a gusher. VERY well carbonated, with a MASSIVE head, no matter how carefully poured. Pours a lightly cloudy deep amber/copper, with the aforementioned inches thick white head, but the lacing is quite poor. Nose is a bit tarter than usual, if I had it blind, I might pick this out as a gentle Cantillon, rather than a more asertive 3 Fonteinen, lots of sweaty horse, plenty of white grapes, leather, grass/straw, seems to be missing a bit of "oomph" in the midle of the nose though... Flavours are nicely sour, very round, very broad and dry, with plenty of salty complexity. Lots of damp barnyard straw, delicate sourness, big, robust body. A rather atypical Drie Fonteinen to me, but a thoroughly enjoyable Gueuze, and a cut above most anything else out there.
Nice!   Orange, lemon, wood and a nice citrus finish that is well blended and doesnt make ya pucker.  This style is growning on me.

Bottle shared at Tkrjukoffs CCB-day in Sätila. Pours hazy golden with a small off-white head. Citrus in the aroma, root cellar, stable. Well balanced to the taste, citrus, root cellar. Very nice one!

Bottle shared by Tim.  What a treat.  Pour is a beautiful clear light honey gold, with a bone white head that fades to a white skim on top, with some soapy lacing.  Aroma is insane.  Lots of tart dusty basement funk, lots of floral character.  Just great.  Taste falls slightly flat after the insanity of the aroma, with lactic and lemon, light funk.  Very nice!
Bottle shared by MatSciGuy!  Clear yellow pour, almost no carbonation and an EXTREMELY dirty sour aroma.  Flavor is light soured apples, pears, very funky and dry on the aftertaste.  Very enjoyable.

Pour out of 375 mL bottle, big thanks to Tim for opening this! Clear orange pour with thin to no head, slightly white, aroma has notes of nice musty basement, vanilla, biscuit, bread, touch of lemon, lactic notes, touch of earth, slight parmesan, cheese.  Taste is funky dusty basement, slight parmesan and bread, some hints of vanilla, lemon, biscuit, finishing with dry and more dusty notes, nice sourness but restrained.  Tasty stuff.

Bottle This beer rocks!... Murky golden ale with a small, fizzy, white head. Good retention. The bouquet is an earthy, funky, acidic swirl of lemon, barnyard, horseblanket and old wet leather. Light to medium-bodied and astringent with airy, mildly stinging carbonation. The flavor is super acidic and lemony with nuances of manure, funk, bread and yeasty bitterness. Well-balanced overall. Finishes tart, and then Sahara dry.  Another world class brew generously shared by darkguardian!
Muy buena combinacion.Balanceada en todos los aspectos aunque bastante compleja.notas a manzana,albaricoque.......recomendable

A steady pour into my Large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a one finger thick, pale tan colored head. The beer is  light amber color that sows a almost clear, orange-amber tinged, full gold color. The aroma smells musty, lactic, slightly woody, musky, funkily phenolic, touches of urea, and just a bright, sharp acidity. A nice grain character comes through as the beer warms up and contributes nutty pale grain notes, a touch of straw, and even a hint of grassiness. I could smell this one for days, there is nothing quite like the aroma of a good, complex Gueuze.

This has a sharp acidity to it without being overly aggressive, but this is certainly has a full on sourness. The acidity accentuates a touch of sour grapefruit character, and perhaps some lemon like notes, but it is certainly full on Lactic. There is enough carbonation to contribute a liveliness and a carbonic bite towards the finish. This has that perfect Gueuze body in that it somehow has a certain fullness to it, but remains light and quaffable. The finish has a phenolic character to it that is slightly medicinal, definitely musty and funky, and perhaps a touch plastic like. Notes of urea, a touch of apple, and grain notes of hay, nutty rustic white bread notes, and some hay like flavors add some extra complexity.

As compared to the Bambic I had earlier, this is clearly a certifiable Gueuze Lambic. This is very nice, and I wish I had a few more bottles of this stocked; a 375ml bottle of a good Gueuze is never enough, and actually my glass of this is gone way to soon, as I am clearly wanting more of this than I have.

375 ml bottle from Belgium. Pours a deep copper color with a medium eggshell white head. The aroma has that bursting fruit and barnyard funk from a 3F Geuze. The flavor is awesome; sweet rich oak, hay, funky, fresh apples and especially apricots. Lovely. Very tart but also very drinkable. Very complex and likely to gain with age.

Afternoon break in Amsterdam, rocket cork, pours golden honey with a huge head, aroma of watermelon, leaves, olives, green tea, floral tones, flavor of wood, acids, lemon, leather and barnyard,  green tea, medium to full bodied, excellent brew

375ml bottle from Belgium order

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 2*375 ml bottle shared @ tkrjukoffs CCB Day tasting. Pours bright hazy orangish golden with a big fizzy goldenish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sour with overripe apples, lemon juice, lemon zest, grapefruit juice, overripe almost rotten pears, hay, dry soil, orange zest, barnyard, horse blanket, wood, currants and gooseberries. Taste is sour with grapefruit juice, lemon juice, lemon zest, orange zest, wood, gooseberries, unripe currants, green apples, grape zest, barnyard, leather, crackers and dry soil. Mouthfeel is dry, tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour and tart with grapefruit juice, lemon juice, lemon zest, hay, wood, grape zest and unripe currants. Very intense.

(Bottle) Pours hazy dark amber with an off-white head. The aroma holds horseblanket, some citrus, crackers, cheese, light tart tropical fruits and a touch of phenols. Mild and balanced nose. The flavour dry and near heavily acidic with notes of brett, lacto, some subtle biproducts from the fermenting process, citrus, old cheesy hop and cracker-like malt. The mouthfeel tart and fairly soft with a medium carbonation. Citric finish. Near medium bodied.

Bottle at CCB Day, Sätila 2012-07-07. Hazy golden beer with a small offwhite head. Sourish rubber aroma, vinous, sour, leather, stable, perfume, fruity, grapefruit, orange, citrus, lemongrass. Sour flavor, rubber, grapefruit, citrus, leather, stable notes, tart, lemon, hoppy. Very sour, still pleasant and balanced. Long citrus finish with rubber and grapefruit.

Bottle 1 of 2 á 37,5 cl @ CCB Day. Pours cloudy orange amber with a small bubbly white head. Aroma is sour fruity funky stable cellar. Flavor is sour bitter dry funky spicy damn so good. Fnishes bitter sour and funky dry.

Bottle (375 ml) from Biwerkompass.de. Clear amber, medium brief white head. Tart green apples cidery aroma, with some grapefruit and vague horse stable notes. Light to medium bodied, prickling carbonation. Bone dry with high acidity and a bit pungent churny bitterness.

375ml bottle.  Nearly took my eye out.  No joke.  I loosened the cage, started to remove just the cag and POW.  Richoceted off my cheek bone and onto the ceiling.  Would have been worth it.  Pours a hazy gold with a frothy white head.  Nose is awesome, funky, horse, leather, grass, band aid, lemon, citrus.  Flavor is tart, bright citrus, grass, hay, funk, cheese, earthy.  Medium to high carbonation.  Full bodied, tart, acidic finish.  A masterful blend.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  gold pour with a white and fluffy head.  nose is tart, wood, cheese, and lemons.  smooth on the palate, lemon, sour, funky, acidic

Bottle. Tart, citrus peel, dank basement, slight oily petroleum aroma. Golden with a large white head. Tart citrus fruit, musty barnyard, light bitter flavor. Light body, lively carbonation, dry finish.
Bottle (courtesy of xmarcnolanx).  Sour musty lemon peel and hay barn aroma.  Golden yellow with small head.  Musty sour-tart lemon and grapefruit flavor.  Excellent.

Bottle @ Christers. Pours golden with a small white head. Aroma is tart and sour wit oak, cheese, funk, green grapes, barnyard. Taste is well balanced, nice sourness witout going over the top, barnyard, oak, dusty, funky, grapes, cheese. Thin body, lively carbonation, dry finish. Lovely. 250612

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2013 Bottle at Craft.  Thanks to Justin.  good funk and sourNess. Lovely to be honest. Intense subtle just wonderful. Gorgeous. 4.4/5.  I had to have a bottle of this to myself so I got one from Dranken Pauwels.  Drunk on 27 Dec 2013 listening to Achtung Baby and cooking a lamb curry.  Clear gold, thick white head, I had to pour a 37.5cl bottle into 3 glasses it was that carbonated.  Classic lemony funky geuze aroma.  But classy.  More classy than the regular geuze. Wow, just so light and delicate in the mouth.  Wow. Glad I was sat down or I would have had to sit down.  Some salt and vinegar crisp flavour.  It is outrageously good.  I wish I could say why.  It seems to offer more by having less.  But it is so poised, so delicate. The light aroma is simply heavenly.  Slightly too much salt and vinegar crisps for me.  And it something I have got from 3 Fonteinen before.  I do prefer the super drinkability of straight Boon or Girardin. Stay classy Senne Valley. Spectacular beer though.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2012 37.5cl bottle. It pours a clear golden colour with a huge white head. Aroma is funk and barnyard, with sweat, dust and lemon zest. Taste is similar, swet acidic,more  on the tart side, with notes of lemon, dust, horse blanket and tart apricots. Body is medium with good carbonation. Overall, this is truly outstanding and worth every penny.

Bottle. Slightly hazy deep golden with small off.white head. Aroma is malt, wheat, tart, barnyard and a little citrus. Flavour is malt, tart, barnyard, wheat, little lemon, little sour, grapefruit an dry.
Hazy golden with a big off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, barnyard and citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and rather acidic. Rather dry and rather acidic finsh. 250612
Bottle.Nice head with good duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma and taste are stable, brett, straw, leather and malt. Nice and sour yet not too astringent.

Bottle @ WY tasting. Darker blond coloured beer with some medium carbonation and a small white head. Nice grainy and refreshing light sweet sour hinted. Medium to full palate. Finish is nice balanced sour wwith a short herby grainy hint and some fruity notes. Very good.
hazy gold blond coloured sparkling body with a white head a sour fruity wood aroma a soury fruity bitter taste with a sour alcholic bitter finish

tannic, I need to pop open a regular oude geuze to compare but I feel like I get a lot more wood in this one. seems a bit more tame and reserved compared to other 3F. the acidity and tart falls behind the dry, astringent mouthfeel. another solid geuze.

Cloudy apricot pour with a frothy head. Nose is marked by gorgeous soft white wine, stone fruit, must, and basement. The flavor brings more of that lovely combination of classic deep 3 Font funk with peach and other bright fruit character. Subtle, and so balanced. Not nearly as aggressive as a lot of his more recent blends, and this one is just as masterful, just differently so.

Bottle in trade big thanks to mattyb! Pour has a bright orange amber color and a big snapping white head. This puppy has some carbonation in it as the cork started out of the bottle the moment the cage was removed. Aroma is so  bright, lemon rind, medium acidity, oak, white grape skin, peach, and yeast. Really lovely and very clean. Mouth feel is light and crisp with high side carbonation. Flavor breaks out quite a bit of acidity, lemon zest, aged hops, tart peach, yeast, and a long dry finish. This has some intensity to it but it does not get overly acidic.
This stuff was awesome!!! the beer of the day!! so good i only wrote down a score ... . All the toilets in New Yorks police stations have been stolen. Police have nothing to go on.

Bottle at Sour and Bitter. Interesting that the addition of an older vintage seems to lower the complexity and finesse.
Nose: fairly musty, more rustic. Lots of sheepy notes, like some Pecorino Romano.
Mouth: similar cloud-like carbonation to the Armand and Tomme blend, and probably my favorite aspect of this beer. Some floral notes, but overall more bitter, darker, and slightly uncouth.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2012 2011 bottle with many thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a hazed golden hued body and a massive white head that lasts and leaves great lace. Strongly funky and complex brett aroma with some floral notes, spicy, lemon, musty and some peppery phenols. Flavors are extremely tart, lots of lactic acid, massively funky, earthy and musty. Complex and layered brett presence. Cobwebs. Funk is the star of this blend. Very lively bubbles, dry and tart with a long duration. Very nice!

 Re-rate (no score change assessed).  02/17/2012 bottle. Small white head, orange hue. Deep complex funk. Wet leaves, pineapple, leather, vinous, white wine, horse stable, cob webs, tobacco. Sharp acidic aromas. Pineapple and tropical fruit palate, dried apricot, tangy acidity, rich funk, jamy. Medium high carb, dry, good. $22 375ml...I need to try this side by side with the amazing regular gueuze to justify the price difference. Tastes delicious now, I dont see it getting better (albeit not worse) with age.

A couple bottles shared at the Sour and Bitter event.  Pours a hazy bright orange with a white head.  The aroma is wet wood, sharp funky flavors, sharp lemon and orange, sour and dry but still good mineral traits.  Flavor is more aggressive than most of the other Drie Fonteinen geuze, but still refined and very good.  Mushroom, wet wood, lots of lemon and deep, earthy farmyard.  Reminds me of the "Vintage" Drie Fonteinen we drank later in the trip.  Actually liked this one quite a bit, maybe a bit better than the regular geuze and the Tomme blend.
Bottle @ home. Clear golden colour, head quickly gone. Smells sour, white wine, wood, cork and slightly dusty. Tastes sour, fresh, wood, tart. Great carbo, full body.

Bottle shared by Dutchdrebus. Lightly hazy orange to golden color, full sized white head that diminishes quickly. Smell sourness and a bit dusty. Taste sourness, a bit sharp sour but still very balanced, slightly fruits. Medium body, medium carbo. Very very enjoyable!

Bottle from Dranken Geers, Oostakker, nr Gent, Belgium, April 2012 consumed at home 24.05.12  Pours dark gold edging towards amber, some haze. Wonderfully tart but a soft tartness, its an easy drinking and refreshing Gueze, touch classy. Really like this however the aromas not as Gueze like as some, I get some light honey notes along with a flavour that isnt quite as tart or zappy as I am used to, however for me this is a bonus rather than a negative as I prefer my Gueze in more of the Boon mould than the Cantillon end of the scale. Excellent stuff.  A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15 3.8

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 UPDATE: Subsequent bottles have been fantastic. Im sure my first experience with this beer isnt indicative of the overall quality of this brew. Revising my score upwards!

Bottle @ S&B. Hazy golden color with a massive white head. The nose is strong wood and lemony acid. Some blue cheese and dried cork. Notes of oak and semi-vinous acid. The taste is very dusty lemon wood and strong funkiness. Cobweb and hot wood, some smokey peaches and apricots. The bodys strong and full - this could definitely be cellared for a while. Soft carbonation. Overall, pretty good, though Id like to return to this one at a later time!

Bottle @ SournBitter, 2012.
Pours clear dark amberish yellow with a small, frothy, off-white head. Aroma is sharply citric, light funk, doughy wheaty malts. Medium carbonation, fine dry and frothy mouthfeel. Flavour has plenty of funk, citric, apple-peel, tart. Fresh and elegant.

Bottle sample @ Sour & Bitter Dinner, Copenhagen. Clear orange body, fizzy off-white head with moderate longevity. Nose is tart citrus, brett funk, straw and hints of lemon. Taste is lemony zest, barnyard funk, apple peel, vinegar and hints of lime. Palate is lively, with enough bubbles to work with the overall complexity. A nice geuze indeed; this is very good stuff.

10th May 2012Bottle shared at Sour & Bitter. Hazy amber beer, massive pale cream coloured head. Light dry palate, crisp. Dry sourness but not too aggressive. Earthy wood with some tart white wine. Semi dry finish, slightly vinegar. Alright.

Ausgewogen säuerlicher Beginn, stark karbonisiert. Fruchtig, grasig, rund. Die Säure steigt weiter, das Bier bleibt aber absolut balanciert und wirkt nie disharmonisch. Deutliche Hopfennoten. Super! 12/11/11/11/12/11

Bottle shared at bu11zeyes 10,000th rating tasting. 

The beer pours a yellow color with a large white head. The aroma is full of very tart lemons, with some nice wheat and yeast notes, as well as quite a bit of barnyard funk. The flavor is also quite funky, with some nice lemon and wheat notes. There is a medium amount of tartness and some nice yeast notes. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very interesting, funky and tart beer that I am glad I got to try.

Bottle sample at Sour&Bitter. Bottle looks good. Beer in the glass zippy, golden, huge head. Intense sour aroma. Starts strong-sourish, notes of leather, some woody notes, a bit fruity. All in all quite sour, but still well balanced. Nice!

Bottle @ Sour & Bitter 2012. Pours a hazy golden orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity funky oaky tart sour citrus aroma. Fruity sour funky tart grapefruit flavor. Has a fruity oaky funky tart sour finish.
Bottle at Sour & Bitter 2012. Cloudy yellow - white head. Nice sourness, light cheese sourness, fruity, leather, light wooden, grape fruits, barnyard, lovely taste ol gold !!!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 Re-rate 6/2/13: Bottle shared at a sour tasting at Noams office.Hazy orange with a big white head. Aroma of barnyard, manure, leather, oak and fruits. Sour yet delicate flavor with barnyard, sweat and fruits. 9/4/8/4/17=4.2

[5/10/12] Bottle sample at Sour & Bitter. Almost clear orange with a big bubbly off-white head. Very sour aroma with fruits, oak and a bit of leather. Very sour flavor with citrus. Lively carbonation. A very straightforward lambic, somewhat sharp. Really nice. 8/4/8/4/17=4.1
A: grapefruit, lemon, yeasts. A: golden. T: medium sourness, lemony. P: mb, high carbo. O: 19/20. Young, still great

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2016 Kindly shared by Phredrik. Thanks! Pours hazy copper with a beige head. Aroma is rural with some stable notes, vinegar, tart, barnyard, weak sulfur, sour berries, bacteria, some plants, alot of grapefruit, leather and some citrus fruits. Taste of grapefruit, citrus fruits, very tart, barnyardy stable notes, sour berries, orange peel and some leather. Very nice and easy to drink geuze!

Golden with huge white head leaving  little lacings. Lasting film of foam. Nose is super tart witj hay and barn. Taste is tart. hay and sour, mellow bitter finish. Light body with lots of  carbonation.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2012 Sour & Bitter Festival CPH 2012. Hazy golden with a small off-white head. Funky, classic 3F aroma with lots of grapefruit. Sweet-tart flavour with some extra fruity sweetness, and very elegant and complex funky and spicy notes.

Corked bottle. A lot of power behind the cork. Deep golden color. Oak, lemon, grapefruit and grassy notes. Pineapple in the aroma. Sour, oaky flavor with lemon, grapefruit and leather. Young and rough at the edges but already a great geuze.

Aroma is mineral, barnyard, lemon biscuit, and lactic sourness.  
Taste is sour lemon rind, bitter hops, lactic sourness.  A delicate sourness to the beer, with a mineral and barnyard backbone.  
Finish is slightly sweet, some biscuit and lemon pith.  Carbonation is low to moderate.
Very nice.
Golden yellow, almost no head. Super tart. Light to medium palate. Pretty nicely balanced, but nothing too interesting or ambitious.

bottle at Sour & Bitter.  husky grains, strong minerals / concrete mix and musty dried / aged cheese rind / mold in the nose.  later develops touches of dried herbs and flowers. sharp acid with bitter egg shell / sulfur throughout, and the acid and carbonation are surprisingly rough for 3 Fonteinen.  its still still quite complex and layered, but not as much as is expected from this producer, and I fear the addition of the 4th year in the blend threw the balance off in favor of overt acidity and harshness.

Bottle, pours hazy golden. Thanks phredrik!  Aroma: funky, loads of apple, ammonia, gun powder, leather, lacto acid, wood, barn yard, Brett, Taste: apple cider vinegar, Brett, lacto, barnyard, acidic, some sweetness, ammonia, dandelion, quite dry,lemon, grap peel.

Bottle @ S&B. Pours light copper with a nice large head thy dissipates after a minute. Aroma is nice and fruity, grapefruit and lemon peel comes to mind, lots of barnyard, and staple, a bit herbal, s hint of the 4 yo lambic with some of the bretty complexity. Taste is nicely tart, lots of brett comes through - leather, barnyard, staple. Subtle grapefruit and citrus nuances. Still very young, but it's good and has a lot of potential.

Bottle at yespr.
Hazy amber coloured with a huge white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of barnyard, soap, brett and berries.
Fruity and light aciidc flavour of barnyard and oak.
Tart finish.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Small off white head. ARoma of grapy sourness, light leather, barnyard, earth and a light sweet touch. Flavour of earth, tart, leather, barnyard, grape and other sourish notes. Full bodied. Ends on a heavy grapish sourness.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2016 shared by yespr. cloudy orange, small white head.
very well balanced sour and tart aroma, mild barnyard,  very smooth aroma.
flavor is bitter , sour, mellow ,wood, tartness, very tasty, easy-drinking, smooth gueuze.. (8.3.8.3.18)
bottle from kihoskh.  clear dark orange, large fluffy white head. extremely nice gueuze aroma with just the right blend of wood and tartness and sourness, very dry, very sour.  Flavor is leather and sourness, not much else, very straight, well balanced and super tasty and refreshing.  i cant remember ever having a gueze this good.
37.5 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry barnyard. Orange fruity and citric. Dry wooden, citric and barnyard. Fruity and solid citric finish. Smooth and fruity finish.
Hazu golden with a medium off white head. aroma had oak, apples, barnyard and leather. Sour flavor with leather, barnyard, wood and sour apples. Taster quite young. Sour dry finish.

Bottle 37,5 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a deep amber with a slight haze and a small off-white head. Dry, farty, sulphurous Brett aroma. Fairly dry and light body, heavy Bretty and sweaty with quite some tannins. Very, very dry and not overly complex. 080512

Bottled. A hazy dark golden beer with a huge yellowish head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, lemons, wood, and horse blanket. The flavor is sweet with notes of lemons, grapefruits, brettanomyces, wood, caramel, and wood, leading to a tart finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.

375ml bottle. pours a hazy golden, more on the yellow side. highly carbonated which led to a large white head that doesnt last long. wet barnyard funk aroma and a bit fruity. taste was a well balanced mix of tart and sour with fruit up front and a juicy dry finish. good stuff!

05/05/2012 Brasserie 4:20, bottle shared by Federico. Dorata, intensa, viva, lievemente torbida, opalescente, schiuma fine e abbondante, bianca, persistente. Aroma di lieviti selvatici, netti sentori agrumati, limone. In bocca è acida, secchissima, pulita. Corpo medio, carbonazione abbondante, con perlage finissimo. Molto buona, chissà invecchiata...

Clear golden colour, slight white bubbles on top. Fruity aroma, malty, citrus and grapefruit. Lovely. Very dry, light tart flavour, quite some wood. Dry finish, wood, quite astringent. Very nice, the 4yo Lambic really makes a difference!
(From 37,5 cL bottle @ De Nacht van de Grote Dorst, Eizeringen)

375 ml bottle.  The cork bursts open as soon as the cage is released.  Pours a clear golden amber with a big white head that disappears quite quickly and leaves some lacing on the glass.  The aroma is lots of funk, some lemon, and quite a bit of grapefruit.  There is also a light earthiness as well as a mineral note.  The taste is quite tart with oak, lots of grapefruit, some lemon, a hint of green apple.  It has a light sweetness to it.  The finish is earthy and funky.  Medium body.  Medium-high carbonation, but not as high as I would have expected with how the cork came out.  Another great blend from Armand.   Not quite as good as the Armand4 series, but still quite good.  More grapefruit flavor than any other gueuze Ive had before.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2015 375 ml bottle - pours golden (yes!). Aroma of sherry, apple vinegar. Medium body with very gentle and full moutfeel to sheer sourness in the middle and tearing everything dry in the finish. But this all with a silk overlay and the perfect (yet vivid) carbonation. Quite a beautiful geuze. Did I mention the carbo level is incredible? As is the beer! 
---
2014 vintage is yet another masterpiece: sweet sour apple in the nose, soft hay and funk on the palate. Incredible over and over again.

375 ml bottle shared by bsuedekum- thanks a ton, Blake! Dated 17/02/2011, best by 02/2021. Pours a hazy gold color with a big white head. Notes of funk, oak, cheese, cork, lemon, yogurt, barnyard, and bread. Light-medium bodied, with a dry, sour mouthfeel and medium-high carbonation. Itd be interesting to try this again in a few years; I like the other 3F geuzes better for the most part but whos to say this couldnt improve even more.

Nice lightly hazy yellow, frothy white head.  Barnyard aroma! Manure, wet hay, lemon zest, yeast, wet dog.  Flavor is tart, spritzy, funky, yeasty, cheesy.  Damn good.  Really damn good.  And the best part is that this beer is going to get better!
Pour hazy yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is barnyard, funk, lemon and grass. Flavor is big on the barnyard and funk. Also has hints of lemon and grapefruit. Pretty good gueze overall.

Bottle, poured into a 3 Fonteinen tulip.  Slightly hazy and golden orange in color.  Some blonde highlights and a massive, frothy, white head on this.  Loads of carbonation, as you can see a bunch of tiny bubbles continuously floating to the surface of the beer.  Other than the slight haze this is looks absolutely amazing.  Very fruity aroma, some oak, and very acidic.  Green apple, green grapes, and peach all appear.  My mouth is watering just smelling this.  Fairly acidic on the palate, but not as overpowering as I first expected.  Maybe a bit thing, sadly.  Oak, peach, some funky cheese, and finishes tart and sour.  I really enjoyed this, but it still could have been better.

Poured into a tulip. 2011 vintage, which is given a 10 year lifespan.

4.0 A: Lots of carbonation in this. The cork started moving as soon as I started twisting the cage. It took more than a few pours to fill the glass up due to the plentiful head. Well hazed (probably from the many pours) light orange brown color. Big frothy white head. Good retention and plentiful lacing.

4.5 S: Lots of fruity funk in this. Plenty of apple with lemon backing it up. Lots of farm aromas in this - apple orchard, dry wood from a barn, hay, livestock. Mildly cheesy and minor musty notes. Not very sour smelling, but plenty of tangy lactic acid giving it the pleasant fruitiness.

4.5 T: Like the nose, this is very fruity and funky. Apple is all through this. Light lemon zestiness underneath. Super woody, but not all from the oak. More like dry, dusty planks of wood. Slightly metallic. Light, though appreciated, cheesiness. Load of lactic acid and perhaps a touch of acetic as well. Less "barny" than the nose suggested, but much more earthy. Wet grass, apple orchard, rotting wood, and must.

3.5 M: Normally Id probably give this at least a 4.0, but Im pretty sure the Armand4s have spoiled just about every other gueuzes mouthfeel for me. Very active, spritzy carbonation. Good there, but missing the creaminess that the seasons gave me.

4.5 D: Very tasty, super complex gueuze. Im more than happy that I purchased a few more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-01-2012 03:05:50

Bottle. Beatiful copper body. Nice aroma with grains and nuts. Some dried fruit. Taste is very balanced in its complexity. Well rounded sourness, even some slightly sweet yellow fruit tones. Aftertaste has some great dry bitterness.

Bottle: Medium vast lively bit airy white head, which disappears with regular speed and leaves a airy thicker white lacing on top of a light cloudy to an almost clear darker golden colored beer. Aromas of wild yeast, oak, earth, apple juice, sweet older grains, older soury hops, light tartness, light creamy fruit notes like apricot and berries. Taste is gently sour, with old hops, some spices, earth, brett/wild yeast, light vinous, older light sharper grains and wood and a light yoghurt sourness which keeps gently souring on into the aftertaste and beyond. Very nice. Gentle tart brett hoppy older grainy oaky aftertaste. Medium carbo, soft mouthfeel upfront and a light tingly sharper mouthfeel in the back (typical geuze), an almost full body and a texture between watery and creamy, leans more towards creamy. Good stuff, gentle tartness and very well balanced. Old fashioned delicious.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: bottle, from bu11zeye 10k, cloudy yellow with white foam, very tart and peppery aroma and flavor, bright body , brett and funk finish

Bottle shared by CaseyK...thanks Casey! Pours light amber with a thin white head. Musty, earthy nose with cheesy citrus and a nice tartness. Taste is bitter citrus rind, tart but not overly so. It dries out nicely, really bitter, with some white grape and cheesy funk. Good stuff--much funkier than the regular Oude Gueuze.

Bottle from bu11zeyes 10K tasting.  Cloudy yellow pour with a small white head.  Aroma is sour fruit, sharp cheese, and lots of wood.  Taste is more old fruit, wood spice, lots of funk, and apple cider vinegar.

(375ml bottle)  Pours a lightly hazy yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of lemon, earth, barnyard, grapefruit, straw, cheese, grass, and wood.  Flavor of grapefruit, lemon, earth, and plenty funky with a dry wood finish.

FREE bottle from MattyB.  Thanks so much for your generosity.  Well the carbonation is very high in this one.  Tomme take note.   Opened the cage and cork was already 80% out; luckily i had my hand over it and was able to make it to the sink without losing any of this precious geuze.   Once the massive head dies down it settles out nicely with lots of lace and a layered orange yellow color.   Nose is fantastic- lots of wood, leather, citrus, funk,  barnyard, cheese, mushrooms, earth.   Flavor is nice as well with mild acidity, notes of funk, lemon, pepper, wood.  Very good now, should age nicely.
Look is golden in color, thinner white head. The smell is wheat, tart, acidic, and funky. The taste is tart, sour, wheat, and funky.
Cloudy gold with a small white head. Aroma is of funk, lemon, hay. Taste is of funk, lemon, earth. Very dry.

(375ml bottle) clearish deep gold, lasting and effervescent bubbles. Nose of wood char, fresh wood barrel with no esters, lemony, a touch of cedar, tart and funky, smells just delicious. Taste of lemon, a bit of wood esters, bit tart, nice and well carbonated.

Put on your safety glasses; the cork will explode out of the bottle.  Pours cloudy orange/amber color with a huge white head.  Intense funkiness as you would expect from Drie Fonteinen.  Lots of must, oak, lemon zest, earth, and mineral.  Soft tartness to it.  The tartness is there in the form of lemon and green apple, but the funk is where this beer really shines.  Lots of earth, must, mineral, and sweat to be had.  Really awesome stuff!

Explosive. Shot everywhere, filling the room with aroma of fruity and light vinegars, funk, and sour lemons. Deep yellow cloudy color. Slight sourness causes a clenching int he back of the jaw. flavor is sweet pale malt, wheat, and cheese.

Bottle from overseas. Served in a Drie Fonteinen "3" gueuze tumbler side-by-side with Drie Fonteinen Oude Geuze bottled on November 18, 2010. The Golden Blend was bottled on February 17, 2011.

The cork started to pop out right after I started to release the cage. Its not a gusher, but this thing has plenty of carbonation. The pour was difficult, to say the least. Loads of foam leading to a very rocky, dense head that leaves behind a nice bit of lacing. Thin cap throughout.

The nose brings an incredible amount of funk and is reminiscent of the Armand4 Herfst and Winter. This is what I love. There some minerality and an earthy mushroom-like character, coming close to a light bit of truffle. Some sweat and goatiness comes along after that. Some backing acidity comes through, leading into the flavor.

First impression in the flavor is sweaty horse blanket mixed with some strong earthiness. Straight from the ground here. Theres some acidity and must that really longer. A bit of leather and very light oak. This is an absolutely gorgeous beer. The acidity and funk flow right into one another. Simply sublime.

The body is light, bordering on light-medium. Pod carbonation and a mild acidity. Heavy funk and earth at every turn. Spritzer-like carbonation. Everything about the body helps to deliver the maxim amount of funk.

What can I say about this? Armand has simply nailed it once again. Breathtaking. I love it.

Aroma:græs vinøs eddike grape  Ud.:gylden klar Skum:hvidt tæt langh  E.smag:sur meget Krop: medium For.: tør Brus: livlig   
Bottle @ AA-Meeting  23/3 12

Clear medium orange pour with a large rocky white head.  Nose is really buggy, musty, funky, juicy.  Citrus pulp and mineral.  Deeply oaky and musty, more so than most Armand blends.  Medium sourness throughout the palate, very dry and woody on the back end.  Lots of mushroom, duty funk in there, definitely more than with the regular Oude Geuze.  Carbonation is high, hopefully will become more champagne like with age.  Lovely beer, of course.

Bottle at home. It pours hazy orange, with a massive off-white head. The nose is floral (particularly elderflower), white grape, vinous, sweet tangerine, pear, and weirdly enough roast chicken flavoured crisps. The taste is lemon, tart green apple, sour white grape, white currant, white grapefruit, vinous, grass, hay, floral and vinegar with a tart, slightly citric finish. Medium body and lively carbonation (perhaps  a touch too much). A very well made gueuze, I imagine this will only get better with time.

Bottled on 17/02/11
Tasted on 4/7/12 from a corked and caged 375mL bottle that shot the cork out and started to gush, at a tasting with the Nashville crew.  Pours hazy golden orange with a thick white head that slowly recedes to thin lace.  The nose is super dry and funky with some hazy, sour lemon pith, a touch of vanilla, and a vinous hint of white wine vinegar.  The flavor is a bit more fruit forward, with some gooseberry, nice lemon oil and pith, hay malt, and the same vinous white wine vinegar from the nose.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long, tannic and sour lemon pith finish.

Bottle via Mattyb83s purchase. Pours a nice orange with big white head.  Aromas is wet hay, funk, tart and some cherry.  Taste is very nice with a nice amount of tart/hay/sour that I dont pick up in the standard Oude Geuze. Not as dry but in a very good way. Overall, outstanding. Something I hope to pick up, canned, in a six pack soon when they open in Ashville.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Bottle to tulip (thanks to urbancaver for including me in on his Belgium order). Looks good; light and inviting with ample carbonation. Smells good too; tart and dry. Tastes good too; much like it smells, only more pronounced. Mouthfeel is good for its type. Overall, a tasty treat every once in awhile.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2012 Bottle opened April 5, 2012
A: Hazy golden orange body.  Massive cobweb like head forms right away.  Dense lacing.
S: Musty, old cellar notes dominate. Wet hay, minerals, earth, funk, light oak, solid juicy lemon complexion.
T: Big juicy citric notes dominate, musty oak, a little funky cheese, earthy. 
M: Medium bodied, solid carbonation, juicy in the middle, dry in the finish.  A bit more sour than normally seen in Armands blends.
O: A very nice blend from Armand, which is no surprise. Has all of the classic Drie Fonteinen characteristics with a bit juicier profile.  Reminds me quite a bit of Herfst in the nice balance between earth/funk/juicy citrus.  Another winner.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured golden (naturally) with a bubbly, lacy head.  Classic 3 Fonteinen yeast characters and funk.  Barnyard, musk, horse blanket with added wood and oak characters, lemon juice acidity to balance.  Foamy, well carbonated on the palate. Drying towards the finish.

golden pour, puffy white head reduces to oily  top, heavy lacing. Super musty lactic nose, heavy cobweb, cereal, and lemon. flavor shows heavy lactic and hay, cobweb, lightest acetic through finish, carbonation adding to lighter body. More acetic, cobweb than Doesjel 750, less salt and balance, higher carbonation and bitterness reminding of 09 Oude Geuze 750s.

Thanks Brad! Typical golden 3 Fonteinen pour with a mountainous rocky white head. Excellent musty hay in the nose with hints of juicy fruit and barnyard coming through in the background. The taste is also classic 3 Fonteinen- excellent dry champagne like musty funk with horse and juicy fruits to complement it all. The palate is medium in body for the style, with excellent fluffy carbonation and a dry and crisp  finish. This didnt remind me of any of Armands special blends like the J&Js, Millennium, or the Armand4 series. It was more like the classic delicious "regular old blend" that one would find in a modern bottle. This, of course, automatically makes it awesome.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2012 Big moldy grapefruit nose, tons of carbonation,  creamy palate,  nice 3  Fonteinen funk. Very champaign -like. Very nice.

375mL thanks to ygtbsm94. Pours hazy, deep orange. Thick, white head. Rich, super dense Valencia orange nose, thick and juicy. My lord. Taste is tangy, very musty, huge attic, huge molded white grapefruit. Quite aggressively sour. Rich and powerful. Great stuff. Heavier carbonation. Would love to see how this progresses.

Bottle.  Pours hazy gold wth average, fizzy white head; decent retention and spare lacing.  Aroma is citrus and tropical fruit, straw, light grassy hops, sour notes, and sweet malt.  Flavor is heavy fruit esters with supporting malt; crisp finish.  Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94.  Pours hazy orange with a large, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is black walnut, lemon zest, acidic fruits, straw and hay malt with light, spicy hops.  Flavor is malt with acidic fruits, black walnut, oak, earthy notes, spicy hops and a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation, light warmth.

Bottle at a tasting at James place, courtesy of Steve.  Pours a hazed gold with a medium to large beige head.  Super funky, big barnyard, cheesy, musk.  Loads of big musky funk, wood, tons of cheese.  Barnyard, loads of cheesy funk.  Absolutely delicious.  Bigger and funkier than most, but full of that classic Drei Fonteinen charm.  Love this.
Bottle thanks to Steve! Pours clear gold with white head. Nose/taste of funky tart lemon, aged cheese, basement funk, oak and cheese cloth. Medium body.

Bottle at Vilvordia. Lively cork, but not a gusher. Hazy variegated golden color, small white head. Amazing aroma of funky lemons, straw. Tasteis dusty lemon skins, rising bread dough. Very hi carbonation interferes with the flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 375 ml bottle.  17/02/2011 "Lotnummer" consumed march 25th, 2012.   pours a clear dark golden with a huge big bubbled dirty white head.  pour slowly.   Big potent aroma of horseblanket, lime, old  dusty damp basement cellar,   and some cheese funk.  as at warms, old dank wet sharp oak and soft leather emerge.  definitely has that classic drie fonteinen gooze character.   seeds in place for for this to evolve nicely with age-  some awesome clean complex funk character reminicnent of some awesome drie fonteinen vintage gueuze blends in the nose, as well as the taste of that classic awesome house character taste found in zomer and even blauw.     touch too acidic, but the acidity is more balanced as it warms. eh, still too acidic though.  taste is a bright lemon juice, clean soft cowhide, farm air on a foggy day, old cobwebs and cheese cloth funk. big time carbonation.  quite interested to see how this develops.   comes across a young gueuze with potential for greatness.  very good right now, but too much lemon juice acidity takes away from the budlight drinkability score.    


rerate bottle feb 15th, 2013.   bottled about 728 days ago.   WOW.  this has developed very nicely.   beautiful.  one i tasted this a year ago i thought it was too acidic.  today, it is perfect.   reminds me of zomer and blauw.    patent drie fonteinen musty leather old grandad funk.    ultra nice.  this is perfect right about now.  but curious what it will be like in 1 more year.  gotta fall off sometime.  this is just about too good right now.    rate after 13 months in bottle:  4.2.  rate after 24 months:  4.8.   Split the difference and give this a 4.5 for now!

Bottle @ VBPF12.
Bouteille souvre sur une belle pression en bouteille qui pour moi suggère que la bière est loin dêtre prête à déguster et demande encore pas mal de temps en cave.
Dorée/orangée, col blanc épais disparaissant assez vite.
Arôme est renfermé, sec, bouquet de grains suivi dun houblon sec, fruité sur des notes citriques et un duvet de foin.
En bouche, je ne vois pas vraiment de grande nouveauté venant de lusage de lambic de 4ans. Palais est sec, note de grange, cave gardant une pointe sucrée qui pourra satténuer avec les années. Fin de bouche sec, fleuri. Le tout reste très jeune, vraiment à laisser en cave qcq années.

24/III/2012 - 37,5cl bottle @ VBPF 12 (Jette) - BB: n/a (2012-273) Thanks to John for sharing the bottle!
Clear orange beer, small yellowish head. Unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: very peppery, lemon, vinegar, citric acid. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: lemony, bit fruity, orange peel, peppery, little bitter. Aftertaste: sour, lemony, also bitter.

A1: EXPLOSIVE POP! This beer was so excited for me to try it that it couldnt help but rocket launch the cork off the top as soon as I twisted the cage far enough. Hazy, medium golden orange. 4+ (big, bubbly white) fingernail head, that dissipates to almost nothing fairly quickly, on soft pour. A2: Smells like a farm (in the best way possible) on a warm summer day - dry barnyard funk, cracked hay, and must. Touch of fruit, soft oak, and more funk. Open-arms inviting! T: Lots going on here. Upfront lemon rind and citrus are combined with smooth tartness (touch of green apple) followed by immediate funk. Middle to back includes mild (fruit) sweetness right before the classic gueuze sourness. Just as the sour fades there is a touch of very distinct, robust earthiness that rounds out this masterpiece wonderfully. Bravo! P: Medium body with loads of carbonation. Prickly on the tongue, but in such a good way. So easy to drink my glass was empty too fast. O: All-around this beer is beautifully blended and put together! I can definitely understand, support, and appreciate the name and think/hope this will only develop into another superb gueuze as it grows older. Considering how young it is at the moment, I was very impressed. I do think it needs a bit of age before reaching its peak, but it drinks amazingly well for where it is right now. Well done (again) Armand on a beer that will fill my cellar and make me smile for many years to come!

Corked bottle, courtesy of Alex (nightfall)Hazy deep blond color; medium sized head, a thin layer is persistent. The aroma is very pungent, a punch actually in the beginning; powerful and elegant Bretts, perfectly balanced. Tart and astringent flavor, you can feel some old and some young element, with a strong astringency and some lemon peel feeling; salty; maybe too astringent and a bit harsh to reach the highest spots, but still very good.
Bottle @ AA-Meeting, Western Denmark 2012. Pours cloudy golden with a frothy white head. Manuer, funk, barnyard, fresh straw and grapes. Oude lambic/Oak. Dry and tart.
38cl, new exclusive brew Anno 2012, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex sour brew, woody/bitter and slightly fruity, very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Pours golden bronze with a huge white head that recedes quite fast.  Nose is sour fruits, slight vinegar, some great barnyard funk and leathery notes.  Flavor is sweet and sour througout until the finish hits after than its a very long sour aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is silky and creamy.  The addition of a four year old lambic has made a huge change to the beer.  Outstanding.
